text:
Looking for your next adventure? National Geographic‚Äôs picks for #BestOfTheWorld 2025 are here üåé 

Developed by our team of travel experts and global editors, this year‚Äôs list is filled with exciting one-of-a-kind destinations for everyone. From surprising hidden gems to time-honored favorites, special focus was placed on experiences that benefit both travelers and locals alike.

Our bags are packed‚Äîsee where we‚Äôre headed at the link in our bio.

Photograph by @andrea_frazzetta

After 100 years of speculation surrounding his fate, the partial remains of Andrew Comyn ‚ÄúSandy‚Äù Irvine are believed to have been discovered on the Central Rongbuk Glacier below the North Face of Mount Everest. Irvine vanished while attempting to conquer the world‚Äôs tallest peak in 1924, along with climbing partner and renowned mountaineer George Mallory. The mystery of whether they reached the summit before their deaths has intrigued climbers and historians for decades.

‚ÄúAny expedition to Everest follows in the shadow of Irvine and Mallory,‚Äù said @jimmychin, who made the discovery with climbers and filmmakers @erichroepke and @therealmarkfisher while filming for an upcoming @natgeodocs project. "Sometimes in life the greatest discoveries occur when you aren‚Äôt even looking. This was a monumental and emotional moment for us and our entire team on the ground, and we just hope this can finally bring peace of mind to his descendants, and the climbing world at large.‚Äù

Read the exclusive story at the link in bio for more on what this discovery means for the history of mountaineering.

Images by @jimmychin @erichroepke and Mount Everest Foundation / @RGS_IBG via Getty Images

Holmes and Watson. The Three Musketeers. Some things work better together‚Äîand that's especially true when it comes to food.

When certain vitamins, minerals, and nutrients are eaten together, they can have a bigger health impact than when eaten separately. This concept is called nutrient synergy, where the whole is greater than the sum of its parts.

Science shows that consuming these vitamins and minerals in unison can boost your nervous and immune systems and improve heart health. Learn more about nutrient synergy at the link in bio.

Photograph by BDMcIntosh, Getty Images

Photos by @ladzinski | With one of the highest metabolic rates of any animal on Earth, hummingbirds work so hard that they need to feed every 10 to 15 minutes. They‚Äôre among the great pollinators of an ecosystem, highly competitive, contentious, and all around fascinating. 

I photographed these three species here‚Äîthe ruby-throated, the rufous, and the broad-tailed‚Äîin my backyard as they buzzed from flower to flower in the garden, competing with one another for nectar.

BREAKING: A gigantic coral, now the largest in the world, has been discovered in the Solomon Islands. 

Measuring 112 by 105 feet, this mega coral (Pavona clavus) is longer than a blue whale‚Äîit's even visible from space. Discovered by cinematographer @manusanfelix and the @natgeopristineseas team, it was initially mistaken for a shipwreck due to its vast dimensions.

Learn more about this discovery, its role in the local habitat, and the climate threats it faces at the link in bio.

Photograph by Manu San F√©lix (@manusanfelix), National Geographic Pristine Seas

Photos by @babaktafreshi | On a starry night in Puerto Rico, a stingray approaches the surface of a bioluminescent bay. The motion triggers the glowing of phytoplankton, creating a magical moment as I was kayaking under the Milky Way. Swipe to see more. 

Some marine plankton species glow in the dark to startle predators or make them visible to other creatures that might prey on them. 
As part of the Life at Night Atlas project with the National Geographic Society, I document the natural rhythm of nocturnal life on Earth and the impact of light pollution. There are hundreds of bioluminescent bays in the world, but Puerto Rico's Mosquito Bay is notable to travelers and scientists for the density and year-round activity of its glowing plankton. The condition arises from the bay‚Äôs shallow depth and narrow and long water entry, which controls water temperature and minerals; the surrounding mangrove forest, which makes the bay water saltier than the ocean; and the lack of modern development in the lagoon.

In Quinten Geldhof's (@microhobbyist) footage of a baby tardigrade riding a nematode, small creatures make a big impression üì∏ 

This video is part of the winning selections from the @nikoninstruments #NikonSmallWorldInMotion competition.

With winter fast approaching, many of us dread losing daylight‚Äîbut did you know that darkness can be surprisingly good for your well-being?

According to scientists, spending time in the dark can have several health benefits including DNA repair, reduced inflammation, and much more. 

Learn how to embrace the benefits of darkness at the link in bio.

Photographs by @navaneeth_unnikrishnan

More @judvhmusic? If you insist üòè For a young meerkat, one of the most important lessons is how to deal with a venomous Cape cobra‚Äîperhaps the most dangerous adversary a meerkat will ever face in Africa's Kalahari desert. Luckily, it's also one that this meerkat won't have to face alone.

Made with fresh ingredients and seasonings, koi is a dish that truly showcases the diverse flavors of Thai cuisine.

Watch the latest episode of @migrationology's Thailand trip on Epic Food Journeys with Mark Wiens on YouTube now at the link in bio.

Photo by @joelsartore | Meet the Asian house shrew. Originating from the Indian subcontinent, this species traditionally resides in forests but has become a common fixture in human households and communities. Mouselike in appearance with a long, pointed nose, these shrews can vary widely in color, size, and weight. While they may have adorable looks, their scent is less than appealing thanks to well-developed scent glands. Used to deter potential predators, the glands produce a strong, musky odor when activated. This photo was taken at Plzen Zoo in the Czech Republic. 
To see more species featured in the Photo Ark, follow me, @joelsartore. 
#PhotoArk

The ‚ÄúBalkan breakfast‚Äù has captivated social media‚Äîbut is it as authentic and healthy as it looks, or just another viral food trend?

This colorful spread of cured meats, bread, pickles, and more may look delicious, but some experts caution that it oversimplifies the region‚Äôs actual breakfast traditions.

Learn more about the ‚ÄúBalkan breakfast‚Äù and what experts say about its history and nutritional value at the link in bio.

Photograph by Eugenia Maximova, Anzenberger/Redux

Photo by @amivitale | An orphaned moose browses at Yukon Wildlife Preserve near Whitehorse, Canada. The preserve is a sanctuary for more than a dozen native species, many of which have been given a second chance at life. Yukon moose, the largest subspecies found across Canada, can stand up to six feet tall and weigh nearly a ton. An important keystone species, they significantly impact the health and dynamics of various aquatic environments. Their herbivore diet plays a crucial role in controlling the abundance and distribution of plant species, which in turn shape the composition and functioning of these ecosystems.

Don't feed the bear! üêª National Geographic photographer @jasperdoest came face-to-face with this hungry brown bear on assignment in Romania, offering an immediate reminder of the issues that arise when bears develop an appetite for human food after being fed by tourists. 

Find out more about how this encounter arose and the challenges facing European rewilding efforts at the link in bio. 

Photograph by @jasperdoest

Is your mess stressing you out? Or do you thrive in chaos?

Everyone these days seems to have an opinion on how your space can best support your mental health, but what‚Äôs the real science?

Head to the link in bio to learn more about how organizing your environment can boost your mood and productivity, and expert tips on how to get started.

Photograph by Laurie Rubin, Getty Images

Photo by @stephenwilkes | Greetings from Botswana. We have begun our journey on the Boteti River. I knew it was a good sign when the moment we arrived at camp in the late afternoon, I encountered this incredible sight of an elephant bathing in a small watering hole.

The heat and dust are in high gear as it‚Äôs the height of the dry season, and this area of the Boteti River is one of the few areas where watering holes exist.

Could a pint of beer actually be good for your health? üçª

Studies overwhelmingly indicate that alcohol is not good for you. But it turns out that hops, one of the key ingredients in beer, offer more than just their signature taste and aroma. Research reveals that antioxidants in hops‚Äîespecially the compound xanthohumol‚Äîcould help regulate blood sugar, among many other surprising benefits.

Head to the link in bio to find out more about the science and history behind hops and its impacts on health.

Photograph by David Levene, eyevine/Redux

Photo by @joelsartore | This beauty is an Asian steppe wildcat I photographed near B√∂lek, Kazakhstan. In the wild, this species can be found in Kazakhstan, western India, western China, and southern Mongolia. While they prefer to be near a source of water, these cats can survive year-round in waterless deserts, frequently using rock crevices or burrows dug by other animals as shelter. In addition to rodents (their preferred prey), the felines supplement their diet with birds, reptiles, fish, insects, and eggs. #PhotoArk

Cold and flu season is here and pneumonia cases are surging. 

It‚Äôs the world‚Äôs leading cause of death for children under the age of five, and the leading cause of hospitalization for adults in the United States.

You may be surprised to learn that there are actually four different types and each has their own causes and risks. Head to the link in bio to find out what experts say you should know about these types ahead of the winter.

Photograph by Living Art Enterprises, LLC/Science Photo Library

Ready for lunch? Cacti in the desert make for a welcome meal opportunity for these bats; but they‚Äôre not just a snack‚Äîthese resilient plants and their unique adaptations could be the key to our future. Learn more about cacti at the link in bio. 

Video by @victor_ammann
Photo by @christianziegler

Can't stop thinking about food? You're not alone.

Unrelated to hunger or food insecurity, "food noise" describes intrusive thoughts about food. For some, it‚Äôs like a nonstop chatter inside their heads about what to eat, when to eat, how much to eat, and so on.

In a world where diet culture constantly influences what we eat, the phenomenon has become increasingly common and distressing for many. Learn more about the science behind food noise, who is most susceptible, and ways to address it at the link in bio.

Photograph by Edwin Tan, E+, Getty Images

Cuteness overload has entered the chat üêª‚Äç‚ùÑÔ∏è‚ù§Ô∏è

#IncredibleAnimalJourneys is now streaming on @DisneyPlus.

Did you see hundreds of Timoth√©e Chalamets all over your feeds last week and wonder why is it that so many people look strikingly similar? 

Research suggests that the most compelling lookalikes have similar genetic traits, despite not being biologically related. Odds are, scientists have found, you might even have a doppelg√§nger out there too.

Learn more about the uncanny and fascinating science behind doppelg√§ngers‚Äîand where you might find your own‚Äîat the link in bio.

First photograph by @francoisbrunelle.doubles
Second photograph by Jeenah Moon for The Washington Post, Getty Images

Well, we couldn't stop at just one @judvhmusic video üêã Bubble-net feeding is a highly specialized form of hunting krill, performed here by a humpback whale as she teaches her calf an important life skill. One day, the younger whale will pass this down to her calf.

Photos by Keith Ladzinski @ladzinski | Weighing upwards of 5,000 pounds, northern elephant seals spend most of their time in the water, diving to depths of more than 5,000 feet to hunt squid and fish, an incredibly taxing way to find a meal. We generally only get a chance to see them beached, when they can easily appear to be lethargic. I photographed this small colony on the coast of central California with my 4-year-old son. As we took in the interesting details of their unique noses, fingernails, and overall massive build, we couldn't help but giggle a little as these animals snored, growled, farted, and battled along the sandy beach.

While many assume that tarot originated in East Asia, researchers now believe it dates back to Renaissance-era Italy. First used as a card game by the elites, it wasn't until late 18th century France that they became a tool for spiritualism, providing solace during times of upheaval.

How did they become what they are today? Discover the history of tarot cards and their unique designs at the link in bio.

Photograph by M. Carrieri/DEA/Album

One day, these baby Eurasian lynx will roam up to 150 square miles‚Äîbut for now, it‚Äôs all about playtime and paw prints üõùüêæ 

#WildNordic is now streaming on @DisneyPlus.

Blooming cacti and the night sky: a desert duo for the ages üåµüåå 

Explore the surprising ways cacti adapt to our changing climate and what it could mean for our own future at the link in bio.

Video by @victor_ammann

For these little cubs, playtime is as important as it is fun üêª

#NatGeoQueens is now streaming on @DisneyPlus.

Protein is key to any balanced diet, providing the amino acids necessary for muscle building, tissue repair, immune system function, hormone regulation, and more.

Yet many don‚Äôt get enough to meet their daily needs. Head to the link in bio to find out how much protein the experts say you really need and the best plant-based and non-plant-based sources.

Photograph by fcafotodigital, Getty Images

In Romania, an ambitious rewilding project is working to restore natural habitats and maintain biodiversity through a new national park. But how will an area of this scale be created? Learn about their efforts at the link in bio.

Video by @jasperdoest

Photo by Muhammed Muheisen @mmuheisen | As the sun sets, people spend time near a canal in the city center of Ghent, Belgium. For more photos and videos from different parts of the world, follow me @mmuheisen.

Moo Deng. Mol√©. Pesto. Biscuits. üíñ

With adorably round features and wobbly movements, it's hard to resist the charms of these viral baby animals. But what is it about them that actually makes our brains buzz?

Read more about the science behind animal cuteness at the link in bio.

Photos by:
Athit Perawongmetha/Reuters/Redux (Moo Deng)
@jenniferhayesig (seal)
@chancellordavid (elephant)

Diaries from an astronaut ‚úçÔ∏è‚Å£
 ‚Å£
NASA astronaut Matthew Dominick reflects on his last few days on the International Space Station (@ISS) before his return, as the undocking for #Crew8 was rescheduled for no earlier than Oct. 13, due to potential impacts from Hurricane #Milton.‚Å£
 ‚Å£
‚ÄúPeering out a Dragon Endeavor window that frames red and green aurora streaming by Dragon Freedom docked to the front of the International Space Station. When Crew-9 arrived, I moved out of my crew quarters on the ISS to make room for @AstroHague.‚Å£
 ‚Å£
I now sleep in Dragon Endeavor while we wait to undock. We take most of our images from the cupola, but sleeping here has been amazing. This is the view out the window this evening. ...‚Å£
 ‚Å£
I miss my family and friends, but we would have missed today‚Äôs insane aurora if we had undocked today. I watched the aurora with Don Pettit today from the cupola and on a later pass I watched it from Endeavor with @AstroHague.‚Äù‚Å£
 ‚Å£
Image description: A window from the Dragon Endeavour, docked on the ISS, peers over Earth. A marbling of clouds is seen from below a vivid green aurora; shades of magenta hover above it in a distance. In contrast, the left half of the window is lit in blue.‚Å£
 ‚Å£
Credit: NASA/Matthew Dominick‚Å£
 ‚Å£
#NASA #Space #ISS #InternationalSpaceStation #Aurora #Earth #Astronaut

Eye see you‚Ä¶ üëÅ

Back in 1996, @NASAHubble revealed the hourglass shape of this young planetary nebula located about 8,000 light-years away. In previous images taken from the ground, the nebula looked like a pair of large outer rings with a smaller central one, but the finer details could not be seen.

Planetary nebulae are created by the death of Sun-like stars: the star collapses to form a dense and hot white dwarf star. At the same time, the dying star throws off its outer layers of material, forming an elaborate cloud of gas and dust known as a planetary nebula. This isn‚Äôt an uncommon phenomenon, and yet, this ‚Äúeye‚Äù star is a little unique: it should be at the center of the nebula, but it‚Äôs off center.

Hubble also revealed other new and unexpected features in the nebula. For example, there is a pair of intersecting elliptical rings in the central region, which appear to be the rims of a smaller hourglass. There are also the intricate patterns of the etchings on the hourglass walls. There are a few possible explanations for the arc-like etchings ‚Äì for instance, they could be the remnants of shells ejected from the star when it was younger.

This picture was composed of three separate images taken by Hubble‚Äôs Wide Field and Planetary Camera 2 in the light of ionized nitrogen (represented by red), hydrogen (green), and doubly ionized oxygen (blue).

Image description: This nebula has an interesting appearance: what looks like a turquoise blue eye stares right at you from the center of a red-orange hourglass-like shape made from two interlocking circles ‚Äì like a Venn diagram turned on its side. The circles each have arcs within them. The darkness of space forms the backdrop of this image.

Credit: NASA/JPL-Caltech/ESA, the Hubble Heritage Team STScI/AURA

#NASA #Nebula #Eerie #Circles #Astronomy

You‚Äôre gonna hear me roar

Have no fear: what might look like a nightmarish beast throwing its head back in an angry red sea is just a pillar of gas and dust. The Cone Nebula is 2,500 light-years away in the constellation Monoceros. This image, captured by @NASAHubble, shows the upper 2.5 light-years of the nebula; the entire nebula is 7 light-years long. Monstrous pillars of cold gas like the Cone are common in large regions of star birth. Astronomers believe the pillars are incubators for developing stars.

Over millions of years, radiation from hot, young stars (located beyond the top of the image) has slowly eroded the nebula. This process causes the hydrogen gas to glow, which produces the red halo of light seen around the pillar. A similar process occurs on a much smaller scale to gas surrounding a single star, forming the bow-shaped arc seen near the upper left side of the Cone. Eventually, only the densest regions of the Cone will be left. Inside these regions, stars and planets may form.

Image description: Against a dramatic red backdrop, a dark pillar of gas and dust stretches upward, its top illuminated by the reflected light of nearby stars. Some stars are sprinkled across the top of the image. There are also a few stars dotting the bottom of the pillar.

Credit: NASA, H. Ford (JHU), G. Illingworth (USCS/LO), M. Clampin (STScI), G. Hartig (STScI), the ACS Science Team, and ESA

#NASA #Nebula #Stars #Universe #Astronomy

Would you want to go on a spacewalk?

In this photo from 2002, NASA astronaut David Wolf is riding the Canadarm2 robotic arm as he installs a camera on the outside of the International Space Station. Wolf visited the @ISS on NASA's STS-112 mission, which sent a crew of six to the station aboard space shuttle Atlantis.

There have been over 270 spacewalks outside the International Space Station since 1998, setting up new experiments, swapping out hardware, and otherwise keeping the orbiting laboratory ship-shape. As we work to grow humanity's presence in low Earth orbit, we're supporting the development of new orbiting destinations‚Äîso your next spacewalk may be closer than you think.

Image description: An astronaut in their spacesuit floats above the Earth. The astronaut is facing right and (from the camera's perspective) is tilted downwards at a 45-degree angle; their feet are hooked into a platform attached to a long, robotic arm. Behind the astronaut, the blue and white shades of Earth fill the background.

Credit: NASA

#NASA #Astronaut #Space #Spacewalk #ISS #SpaceStation #NASAHistory

Excuse me. ü§≠‚Å£
 ‚Å£
On Aug. 31, 2012, the Sun let out quite a burp. A long filament of solar material erupted out from the Sun's atmosphere, or corona, into space. This coronal mass ejection (CME) was captured in different ultraviolet light wavelengths by our Solar Dynamics Observatory, a spacecraft that studies solar activity and space weather. This photo combines those images to give us a detailed view of the solar event.‚Å£
 ‚Å£
This CME traveled at over 900 miles per second (1450 kps), connecting with Earth's magnetic environment. When the particles released during a CME interact with gases in Earth‚Äôs magnetosphere, beautiful displays of light in the sky appear: auroras.‚Å£
 ‚Å£
Auroras happen more often and more strongly when the Sun is at its peak activity level in its 11-year cycle, called solar maximum. You may have guessed that we‚Äôre currently in this peak activity period, given we‚Äôve been able to see auroras several times this year. If you scroll back through our feed, you‚Äôll see a few photos of them.‚Å£
 ‚Å£
We‚Äôll be sure to let you know when there‚Äôs another great opportunity to see an aurora. In the meantime, here are some viewing tips to keep in mind for the next time.

1. Check the weather forecast. You‚Äôll need clear skies to best see the phenomenon.‚Å£

2. Go to a safe, dark location. Strong auroras can be seen even in big cities, but the best views will be in areas with little or no light pollution.‚Å£

3. Be patient! While displays can last all night, sometimes they are much shorter-lived, and they can vary in brightness throughout the night.‚Å£

Check out the link in our bio for more tips!‚Å£
 ‚Å£
Image description: The Sun appears as a bright, fiery red and orange ball. A long thread of material juts out at bottom left. There is a yellow-orange haze around the Sun; in some places, it fans out like feathers.‚Å£
 ‚Å£
Credit: NASA/GSFC/SDO‚Å£
 ‚Å£
#NASA #Sun #Astronomy #Aurora #Atmosphere #Lights

‚ö†Ô∏è ARTIST AT WORK ‚ö†Ô∏è‚Å£
 ‚Å£
Space meets art in one of NASA astronaut Don Pettit‚Äôs ‚ÄúScience of Opportunity‚Äù experiments aboard the International Space Station (@ISS).‚Å£
 ‚Å£
For this specific experiment, Pettit grew thin wafers of water ice using the orbiting lab‚Äôs freezer and photographed them with a polarizing filter in front of a blank computer screen ‚Äî showing off the colorful fragments of ice crystals seen here.‚Å£
 ‚Å£
‚ÄúScience, or should I say Nature, has a way of presenting surprising beauty if one is willing to look.‚Äù ‚Äì Don Pettit‚Å£
 ‚Å£
Image descriptions: ‚Å£
1-3. Colorful ice crystals fill a circular shape. Each image shows different patterns of facets, each fragment a different rainbow hue. ‚Å£
4. Astronaut Don Pettit is at the center of a segment on the ISS working on his experiment. He is wearing gloves, looking behind the camera to his set-up.‚Å£
 ‚Å£
Credit: NASA/Don Pettit‚Å£
 ‚Å£
#NASA #Space #ISS #Art #Crystals #Ice #SpaceStation #Experiments #Science #Colors

A supernova glowing in the dark üåü‚Å£
 ‚Å£
When supernova remnant SN 1006 first appeared in the sky in 1006 C.E., it was far brighter than Venus and visible during the daytime for weeks. From that moment on, it occupied the hearts of astronomers all over the world; it has been studied from the ground and from space many times.‚Å£
 ‚Å£
In this image, visible, radio, and X-ray data combine to give us that blue (and red) view of the remnant‚Äôs full shell ‚Äì the debris field that was created when a white dwarf star exploded and sent material hurtling into space.‚Å£
 ‚Å£
Scientists believe SN 1006 is a Type Ia supernova. This class of supernova is caused when a white dwarf never lets another star go: either it pulls too much mass from a companion star and explodes, or it merges with another white dwarf and explodes. Understanding Type Ia supernovas is especially important because astronomers use observations of these explosions in distant galaxies as mileposts to mark the expansion of the universe.‚Å£
 ‚Å£
Image description: This supernova remnant looks like a bubble filled with blue and red clouds of dust and gas, floating amid a million stars. These stars are visible all around the bubble and even can be seen peeking through it.‚Å£
 ‚Å£
Credit: NASA, ESA, and Z. Levay (STScI)‚Å£
 ‚Å£
#NASA #Supernova #Stars #IVE #Astronomy #Hubble #Chandra #Clouds #ÏïÑÏù¥Î∏å #SupernovaLove #DavidGuetta

A cosmic crustacean ü¶Ä‚Å£
 ‚Å£
A wispy and filamentary cloud of gas and dust, the Crab Nebula is the remnant of a supernova explosion that was observed by Chinese astronomers in the year 1054 C.E.‚Å£
 ‚Å£
The image combines views from two space telescopes: @NASAHubble and @EuropeanSpaceAgency‚Äôs Herschel Space Observatory. Herschel is a European Space Agency (ESA) mission with important NASA contributions, and Hubble is a NASA mission with important ESA contributions.‚Å£
 ‚Å£
Hubble‚Äôs view of the nebula is at visible wavelengths, obtained using three different filters sensitive to the emission from oxygen and sulphur ions and is shown here in blue. Herschel‚Äôs far-infrared image reveals the emission from dust in the nebula and is shown here in red.‚Å£
 ‚Å£
Image description: In this image of a colorful, purple nebula, an oval with complex structure extends from lower left to upper right against a black background. On the oval‚Äôs exterior lie curtains of glowing purple fluffy material. Its interior shell shows large-scale loops of mottled filaments of pink, studded with clumps and knots. Translucent thin ribbons of smoky pink lie within the remnant‚Äôs interior, brightest toward its center.‚Å£
 ‚Å£
The purple material follows different directions throughout, sometimes sharply curving away from certain regions within the remnant. A faint, wispy ring of blue material encircles the very center of the nebula.‚Å£
 ‚Å£
Credit: ESA/Herschel/PACS/MESS Key Programme Supernova Remnant Team; NASA, ESA and Allison Loll/Jeff Hester (Arizona State University)‚Å£
 ‚Å£
#NASA #Space #Astronomy #Crab #Nebula #Stars #Purple

Take a moment to enjoy the beauty of the universe ‚ú®

This image of the "Cosmic Cliffs" in the Carina Nebula, a nursery for newborn stars about 7,600 light-years from Earth, was one of the very first released by our @NASAWebb telescope back in 2022.

The mountains and valleys in this image are actually the boundaries of the nebula; within these massive clouds, young stars and protostars are giving off streams of gas and radiation. Webb's high-resolution, infrared instruments allow it to look through the cosmic dust, giving scientists newfound insight into how stars are formed‚Äîand showing the rest of us the joy and wonder that can be found across our galaxy.

Image description: The image is divided between a rusty red cloudscape, forming a nebula along the bottom portion, and a comparatively clear upper portion. Speckled across both portions is a starfield, showing innumerable stars of many sizes. The upper portion of the image is blueish, and has wispy translucent cloud-like streaks rising from the nebula below. The cloud-like structure of the nebula contains ridges, peaks, and valleys‚Äîan appearance very similar to a mountain range. 

Credits: NASA, ESA, CSA, and STScI

#NASA #Space #NASAWebb #ESAWebb #JWST #Stars #Nebula #Astrophotography

Tiny but mighty üí™

Saturn ice moon Mimas wears its history on its surface. The tiny moon ‚Äì only 247 miles (397 km) across ‚Äì is covered in impact craters dating from the turbulent beginnings of our solar system.
 
Its most distinguishing feature is a giant impact crater named Herschel (not shown here), after the English astronomer who discovered Mimas in 1789. Shock waves from the Herschel impact may have caused the fractures, also called chasmata, on the opposite side of Mimas.
 
Puzzlingly, Mimas appears to be frozen solid. Mimas is closer to Saturn and has a much more elongated orbit than Enceladus, another of Saturn‚Äôs icy moons, so it should have more tidal heating than Enceladus. Yet Enceladus has geysers of water, which implies internal heat, while Mimas has one of the most heavily cratered surfaces in the solar system, which suggests a frozen surface that has lasted long enough to preserve all those craters.
 
This paradox has prompted the "Mimas Test" ‚Äì any theory that claims to explain Enceladus‚Äô partially thawed water must also explain Mimas‚Äô entirely frozen water.
 
Image description: Mimas, a small moon with a heavily cratered surface, is in sharp focus against the hazy edge of Saturn‚Äôs atmosphere. Half of Mimas is visible, while the right side is in shadow. The image is in black and white.
 
Credit: NASA/JPL-Caltech/Space Science Institute
 
#NASA #Saturn #Astronomy #Moon #Crater #SolarSystem #Space #BlackAndWhite

When to look up in November ‚ú®
 
Look out for Jupiter, Saturn, and Mars throughout the month as the planets dance through the night sky.
 
On Nov. 6, set your sights on Venus as our Parker Solar Probe takes its last flyby past the planet before making its way to touch the Sun.
 
Before sunrise on Nov. 27, observers in the eastern half of the U.S. and Canada may be able to witness an occultation‚Äîwhen the Moon passes in front of, and temporarily hides, a bright star‚Äîin this case, Spica.
 
 
Credit: NASA/JPL-Caltech
Thumbnail credit: Bill Dunford
 
#NASA #Space #NightSky #WhatsUp #November #ThingsToDo #StarGazing #Planets #SolarSystem #astronomy

Don‚Äôt turn your back, don‚Äôt look away, and don‚Äôt blink!‚Å£
 ‚Å£
Our @NASAWebb and @NASAHubble telescopes teamed up to keep an eye on a pair of galaxies that are‚Ä¶ staring back? These glaring galaxies have eye-like cores that peer out from a bloody red mask; those grisly colors represent a combination of mid-infrared light from Webb with visible and ultraviolet light from Hubble.‚Å£
 ‚Å£
To date, these galaxies have only grazed each other, but there is some possible evidence of the collision visible in this image. For instance, the bright red lines that make the ‚Äúeyelids‚Äù are potential proof of material from the galaxies slamming together. Those lines may cause the appearance of the galaxies‚Äô bulging, vein-like arms.‚Å£
 ‚Å£
The galaxies‚Äô first pass may have also distorted their delicately curved arms. The diffuse, tiny spiral arms between the left spiral‚Äôs core and its far-left arm may be an example of this activity. Even more tendrils look like they‚Äôre hanging between the galaxies‚Äô cores. Another extension ‚Äúdrifts‚Äù off the top of the larger galaxy, forming a thin, semi-transparent arm that practically runs off this image.‚Å£
 ‚Å£
Over millions of years, the galaxies might repeatedly swing by each other, melding their cores and arms together, eventually leaving behind a completely reshaped arms, and an even brighter, cyclops-like ‚Äúeye‚Äù at the core. Star formation will also slow down once their stores of gas and dust deplete, and the scene will calm‚Ä¶ and we can blink. üòå‚Å£
 ‚Å£
Image description: Two spiral galaxies appear to be dazzling, unblinking eyes set in a bloody mask. The galaxy cores are bright yellow, while the spiral arms swirl around them in shades of pink, white, and blue. The right galaxy is bigger than the one on the left.‚Å£
 ‚Å£
Credit: NASA, ESA, CSA, STScI‚Å£

Highway to the danger zones

Astronomers used data from @NASAChandraXray and our now-retired Spitzer Space Telescope to show where some of the most treacherous places in a star cluster may be, where planets‚Äô chances to form are diminished.

The Chandra data (purple) shows the diffuse X-ray emission and young stars in this star cluster, Cygnus OB2. Infrared data from Spitzer (red, green, blue, and cyan) reveals more young stars and the cooler dust and gas throughout the region.

In a crowded environment like this, there is a lot of high-energy radiation made by stars and planets. Together, X-rays and intense ultraviolet light can destroy planetary disks and systems in the process of forming.

Image description: The Cygnus OB2 star cluster resembles a night sky blanketed in orange, purple, and gray clouds. The center of the square image is dominated by purple haze. This haze represents diffuse X-ray emissions, and young stars, detected by the Chandra X-ray Observatory. Surrounding the purple haze is a mottled, streaky, brick orange cloud. Another cloud resembling a tendril of gray smoke stretches from our lower left to the center of the image. These clouds represent relatively cool dust and gas observed by the Spitzer Space Telescope. Although the interwoven clouds cover most of the image, the thousands of stars within the cluster shine through. The lower-mass stars present as tiny specks of light. The massive stars gleam, some with long refraction spikes.

Credit: X-ray: NASA/CXC/SAO/J. Drake et al, IR: NASA/JPL-Caltech/Spitzer; Image Processing: NASA/CXC/SAO/N. Wolk

If you look closely ‚Ä¶ you might find ‚Ä¶‚Å£

Uranus, pictured as a blue dot in the upper left of this natural-colored image, represents what the human eye would see from the vantage point of our Cassini spacecraft as it flew by Saturn‚Äôs rings. At the time, Cassini was approximately 614,300 miles (988,600 km) from Saturn and 28.3 astronomical units from Uranus. An astronomical unit is the average distance from Earth to the Sun, equal to 93 million miles (150 million km).‚Å£
 ‚Å£
Uranus is a pale blue because its visible atmosphere contains methane gas, and few aerosols or clouds. Methane on Uranus ‚Äì and its sapphire-colored sibling, Neptune ‚Äì absorbs red wavelengths of incoming sunlight, but allows blue wavelengths to escape back into space, resulting in the predominantly bluish color seen here.‚Å£

In the distance to the upper left, visible as a blue dot only a few pixels wide, is the gas giant Uranus.‚Å£

It‚Äôs giving rainbows and unicorns, like a middle school binder ü¶Ñüåà ‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£‚Å£
Meet NGC 602, a young star cluster in the Small Magellanic Cloud (one of our satellite galaxies), where astronomers using @NASAWebb have found candidates for the first brown dwarfs outside of our galaxy.  This star cluster has a similar environment to the kinds of star-forming regions that would have existed in the early universe‚Äîwith very low amounts of elements heavier than hydrogen and helium. It‚Äôs drastically different from our own solar neighborhood and close enough to study in detail. ‚Å£‚Å£
 ‚Å£‚Å£
Brown dwarfs are‚Ä¶ not quite stars, but also not quite gas giant planets either. Typically they range from about 13 to 75 Jupiter masses. They are sometimes free-floating and not gravitationally bound to a star, like a planet would be. But they do share some characteristics with exoplanets, like storm patterns and atmospheric composition. ‚Å£‚Å£

@NASAHubble showed us that NGC 602 harbors some very young low-mass stars; Webb is showing us how significant and extensive objects like brown dwarfs are in this cluster. Scientists are excited to better be able to understand how they form, particularly in an environment similar to the harsh conditions of the early universe.‚Å£‚Å£
 ‚Å£‚Å£
Read more at the link in @ESAWebb‚Äôs bio. ‚Å£‚Å£

Around and within the gas, a huge number of distant galaxies can be seen, some quite large, as well as a few stars nearer to us which are very large and bright.‚Å£‚Å£

Red Wine Supernova ‚ù§Ô∏è

Since its discovery in 1987, this supernova has fascinated astronomers with its spectacular light show. Located in the nearby Large Magellanic Cloud, it was the nearest supernova explosion observed in hundreds of years and the best opportunity yet for astronomers to study the phases before, during, and after the death of a star.

This supernova has been studied by @NASAHubble, @nasachandraxray, and ALMA, a powerful array of 66 antennas, for over 30 years. Here are a few things they showed us, so slow down, sit down, it's new:

- Hubble studies revealed that the dense ring of gas around the supernova (visible at the very center of the image) has a diameter of about a light-year and glows in optical light. The ring was there at least 20,000 years before the star exploded. A flash of ultraviolet light from the explosion energized the gas in the ring, making it glow for decades.

- Chandra data showed an expanding ring of X-ray emission that had been steadily getting brighter from 1993 to 2013. The blast wave from the original explosion has been bursting through and heating the ring of gas surrounding the supernova, producing X-rays.

- Beginning in 2012, astronomers used ALMA to observe the glowing remains of the supernova, studying how the remnant is actually making vast amounts of new dust. A portion of this dust will make its way into interstellar space and may become the building blocks of future stars and planets in another system. These observations also suggest that dust in the early universe likely formed from similar supernova explosions.

Image description: Clouds of gas and dust in shades of red cover the top of the image and a little bit of the bottom. Right in the middle is Supernova 1987a, the remnant of an exploded star. The site of the supernova is surrounded by an illuminated pinkish ring. Two faint outer rings are also visible. Stars and galaxies shine throughout, giving off red and blue light.

Credit: NASA, ESA, R. Kirshner (Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics and Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation), and M. Mutchler and R. Avila (STScI)

On the tails of a comet ‚òÑÔ∏è‚Å£
 ‚Å£
Astronaut Matthew Dominick took this photo of comet Tsuchinshan-ATLAS on Sept. 22, when it was about 100 million miles (160 million km) from Earth. Dominick captured this shot aboard the International Space Station (@ISS) using long-duration photography on a camera programmed for high sensitivity. The comet, which likely traveled from the outer reaches of our solar system, made its closest transit past the Sun on Sept. 27.‚Å£
 ‚Å£
When a comet approaches the Sun, it gets warmer. Heat causes its ice to sublimate into gas, and these gases and dust become a glowing head and tail that can extend millions of miles. The dust tail of Tsuchinshan-ATLAS features prominently in this photo, extending toward the top of the frame.‚Å£
 ‚Å£
A second type of tail, the ion tail, is faintly visible, pointing down and to the right. The Sun influences the two types of tails in different ways, often sending them in different directions. The heat and pressure of sunlight push particles in the dust tail away from the Sun, though the tail may bend slightly in the direction the comet came from. Likewise, the solar wind strips ions off of the comet‚Äôs surface to create the ion tail, which may extend at a different angle.‚Å£
 ‚Å£
Image description: A comet appears to shoot down the center of the image, with a cross-section view of the Earth‚Äôs horizon and atmospheric layers below. From top to bottom, bands of green, yellow, blue, and grey stretch across the image.‚Å£
 ‚Å£
Credit: NASA/Matthew Dominick‚Å£
 ‚Å£

Meet Callisto üåï

The third-largest moon in the solar system‚Äîalmost as big as the planet Mercury‚ÄîCallisto was first spotted orbiting Jupiter in 1610 by the astronomer Galileo Galilei. Callisto has been pummeled by comets and asteroids for 4 billion years, shaping its rocky, icy surface. Scientists think that, like fellow moon Europa, Callisto could hold a massive ocean underneath.

Much of what we know about Callisto comes from a @NASASolarSystem spacecraft named (appropriately) Galileo, which orbited Jupiter and studied its moons from 1995 to 2003. Galileo captured this image of Callisto in May 2001, two years before the spacecraft ended its mission with a dramatic plunge into Jupiter's crushing atmosphere.

Image description: The moon of Callisto, a spherical, mottled ball, as seen from space. Its dark, brownish surface is covered with craters of various sizes and white marks, which are thought to be crater peaks capped with ice. The background of the photo is completely black.

Credit: NASA/JPL-Caltech/DLR

The dangers of bottling up your emotions ‚ö†Ô∏è ‚Å£
 ‚Å£
In the binary star system at the middle of this image, a white dwarf swings by its red giant companion once every 44 years. When it gets too close, it siphons off hydrogen gas, which builds and builds until it undergoes spontaneous nuclear fusion ‚Äì causing an explosion like a hydrogen bomb. The dwarf star‚Äôs outburst ejects geyser-like filaments from its core, forming weird loops and trails as the plasma emerges in streamers.‚Å£
 ‚Å£
The plasma is twisted by the force of the explosion, channeled upwards and outwards by strong magnetic fields until it appears to bend back on itself into a spiral pattern. The plasma in this image is soaring into space at over 1 million miles per hour (1.6 million kph) ‚Äì fast enough to travel from Earth to the Moon in 15 minutes!‚Å£
 ‚Å£
Image description: The binary star‚Äôs core burns in white light as bright blue gas bursts out of it. Two tendrils of hot gas and dust are released to the left and right of the star in shades of red and yellow.‚Å£
 ‚Å£

Behold: a full moon worthy of the Halloween season. The Hunter‚Äôs Moon!‚Å£
‚Å£
According to the Farmer‚Äôs Almanac, this month‚Äôs full moon coincides with deer hunting season. This Hunter‚Äôs Moon is extra special this year because it is also a supermoon, which means that the full moon occurs when the Moon is closest to Earth in its elliptical orbit.‚Å£
‚Å£
At its closest point, the full moon can appear up to 14 percent bigger and 30 percent brighter than the faintest Moon of the year, which occurs when it‚Äôs farthest from Earth in its orbit. Even though 14 percent doesn‚Äôt make a big difference in detectable size, a full supermoon is a bit brighter than other moons throughout the year.‚Å£
‚Å£
This full moon is also important to lots of different cultures across the world. As the full moon in the Hebrew month of Tishrei, this full moon falls near the start of Sukkoth, a seven-day holiday starting on the fifteenth day of the month. For Hindus, this is Sharad Purnima, also known as Kumara Purnima, Kojagari Purnima, Navanna Purnima Kojagrat Purnima, or Kaumudi Purnima. For Buddhists, this full moon marks the end of Vassa, the three-month period of fasting for monks tied to the monsoons. In Myanmar, this full moon corresponds with the three-day Thadingyut Festival of Lights, also known as the Lighting Festival of Myanmar. In Sri Lanka, this is Vap Poya, which is followed by the Kathina festival, during which people give gifts to the monks.‚Å£
‚Å£
Keep an eye on the sky for the next couple days, as the Moon will appear full through the morning of Friday, Oct. 18.‚Å£

Image description: The full moon glows bright gold in the top left of the image. The full moon stands out against a hazy purple sky. In the lower right corner, a snowy peak can be glimpsed, bathed in dark red light.‚Å£

Take a deep breath...

X-ray images from our Chandra X-ray Observatory helped astronomers confirm that most of the oxygen in the universe is synthesized in massive stars. So, everybody say "thank you" to supernova remnants (SNRs) like this one, which has enough oxygen for thousands of solar systems.

Supernova remnants are, naturally, the remains of exploded stars. They're extremely important for understanding our galaxy. If it weren't for SNRs, there would be no Earth, no plants, animals, or people. This is because all the elements heavier than iron were made in a supernova explosion, so the only reason we find these elements on Earth or in our solar system ‚Äî or any other extrasolar planetary system ‚Äî is because those elements were formed during a supernova.

@nasachandraxray's data is represented in this image by blue and purple, while optical data from @nasahubble and the Very Large Telescope in Chile are in red and green.

Image description: The darkness of space is almost covered by the array of objects in this image. Stars of different sizes are strewn about, while a blue and red bubble of gas is at the center. An area of pink and green covers the bottom-right corner.

‚ÄúThe sun goes burp and the atmosphere turns red.‚Äù

So said NASA astronaut Don Pettit, who captured the aurora from the @ISS on Oct. 10, 2024. He and fellow NASA astronaut Matthew Dominick were just about to call it a day and get some sleep, having been unsuccessful in getting a good view of the aurora, when they looked through the cupola windows and realized they were flying in the aurora, not above it.

Auroras are usually created when the Sun sends a surge of charged particles ‚Äì the ‚Äúburp‚Äù ‚Äì through solar flares, coronal mass ejections, or an active solar wind toward Earth. Those solar particles collide with the magnetosphere and compress it, changing the configuration of Earth‚Äôs magnetic field. Some particles trapped in the magnetic field are accelerated into Earth‚Äôs upper atmosphere where they excite nitrogen and oxygen molecules and release photons of light ‚Äì the aurora.

Since the space station became operational in November 2000, crew members have produced hundreds of thousands of images of Earth and natural events like auroras. Their photographs record how the planet changes over time, allowing scientists to study phenomena, monitor disasters, and direct response on the ground.

Image description: Behind modules of the International Space Station is the aurora, a green and red haze curving over Earth. A few stars are visible, too.

Credit: NASA/Don Pettit

Cause we are sisters, we stand together ‚≠ê
 
Surrounded by sweeping clouds of dust are the Seven Sisters. Also known as the Pleiades, this star cluster is 445 light-years away in the constellation Taurus. There are clearly way more than seven stars in this image ‚Äì this star cluster actually contains over a thousand stars loosely bound by gravity. However, a handful of these stars are brighter than their siblings, standing out visually.
 
This image was captured by the infrared camera on our now-retired Spitzer Space Telescope. The colors in the picture correspond to infrared wavelengths: light with a wavelength of 4.5 microns is blue; light of 8 microns is green; and light of 24 microns is red.
 
The Sisters are also visible from the ground. For best viewing, find them with a pair of binoculars in November through March. You‚Äôll find them toward the south in the Northern Hemisphere and toward the north in the Southern Hemisphere.

Count the headlights on the highway... ‚ú®

If you were living in this ‚Äúsuper star‚Äù cluster, you might see a sky full of hundreds of stars, each as bright as the full moon.
¬†
This is @NASAWebb‚Äôs look at Westerlund 1, one of the closest clusters of its kind. Super star clusters are young and contain more than 10,000 times the mass of the Sun packed into a small volume. Westerlund 1 is the most massive yet identified in our galaxy, with 50,000 to 100,000 times the mass of the Sun contained within a region less than six light-years across. Still considered an open cluster now, someday it will evolve into a globular cluster‚Äîa roughly spherical, tightly packed collection of old stars bound together by gravity.
¬†
Super star clusters are one of the most extreme environments in which stars and planets can form. Because our galaxy is past its peak of star formation, and because stars live relatively short lives, only a few of these clusters still exist to give us clues to that past era.
¬†
Westerlund 1 has a large, dense, and diverse population of evolved, massive stars. It contains so many massive stars that in a timespan of less than 40 million years, it‚Äôll be the site of more than 1500 supernovas. This cluster is a natural laboratory for the study of extreme stellar physics, helping us learn how the most massive stars in our galaxy live and die, and how stellar winds, supernovae, and other ejected material affect star formation within their environment.
¬†
Read more at the link in @ESAWebb‚Äôs bio.
¬†
Image description: A dense cluster of bright stars, each with six large and two small diffraction spikes, due to the telescope‚Äôs optics. They have a variety of sizes depending on their brightness and distance from us in the cluster, and different colors reflecting different types of star. Patches of billowing red gas can be seen in and around the cluster, lit up by the stars. Small stars in the cluster blend into a background of distant stars and galaxies on black.
¬†
Image credit: ESA/Webb, NASA & CSA, M. Zamani (ESA/Webb), M. G. Guarcello (INAF-OAPA) and the EWOCS team

#Crew9 soars to the International Space Station! A SpaceX Dragon spacecraft, powered by a Falcon 9 rocket, lifted off Saturday, Sept. 28 at 1:17 p.m. EDT (1717 UTC), on the way to the @ISS. Astronaut Nick Hague (@AstroHague) and cosmonaut Aleksandr Gorbunov will spend about five months working on science and research on the station. Crew-9 is scheduled to return to Earth in February 2025. Astronauts Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams, who launched to the station on a Starliner spacecraft, will join Crew-9 for the journey home on Dragon. This mission is the first-ever crewed launch from Space Launch Complex-40 (SLC-40) at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station in Florida. That‚Äôs not a giant bath bomb, it‚Äôs our Moon!

We usually see Earth‚Äôs Moon in shades of gray, but here in this composite photo made from images captured by our Galileo spacecraft, it‚Äôs a riot of reds, oranges, and blues. And sure, it‚Äôs pretty, but that‚Äôs not the (only) reason we color images.

The unusual colors in this photograph help scientists study what the Moon‚Äôs soil is made of. Areas appearing red generally correspond to the lunar highlands, while blue to orange shades indicate the ancient volcanic lava flow of a mare, or lunar sea. Bluer mare areas contain more titanium than the orange regions do. The deep blue patch on the right is Mare Tranquillitatis, and it‚Äôs richer in titanium than Mare Serenitatis, a slightly smaller circular area to the upper left of Mare Tranquillitatis. Finally, the small purple areas found near the center are deposits formed by explosive volcanic eruptions.

The solid-state imaging system on Galileo captured 15 images of the Moon through three color filters while the spacecraft passed through the Earth-Moon system on Dec. 8, 1992. When this view was obtained, the spacecraft was 262,000 miles (425,000 kilometers) from the Moon and 43,000 miles (69,000 kilometers) from Earth. Galileo continued on to its main mission: studying Jupiter. It orbited the planet for almost eight years, made close passes by all of the planet's major moons, and ended its mission by intentionally crashing into Jupiter on Sept. 21, 2003.

While this image won‚Äôt give you a luxurious bubble bath, meditating on all its colors can be just as relaxing.

Image description: The Moon is awash in shades of red, blue, and orange. The top portion is orange, while the bottom is red, and the middle is blue. The edges of each area are jagged, and some colored portions surround others. There is a very vibrant blue area right of center. The very bottom part of the Moon is missing from this composite image.

Credit: NASA/JPL

#NASA #Moon #Color #Space #Mindfulness #Galileo #Astrophotography

This Saturday, July 6th, Dianna will be LIVE-streaming a full day of her life as someone suffering from ME/CFS and long COVID.

The purpose of the Livestream is to raise money and awareness for those suffering from the disease. All funds will be going to the Open Medicine Foundation (OMF), a non-profit research organization dedicated to finding effective treatments for ME/CFS. (https://www.omf.ngo/)

The Livestream will be viewable at youtube.com/physicsgirl 
From 6:45A.M. (PT. Pacific Time) to 6:00P.M. (PT).

Kyle, Simone Giertz, and Ian Hecox will be answering your questions during the stream, and a few pre-recorded interviews from experts in the field will help us better understand the nature of the disease.

Dianna will not be talking during the Livestream, she will be in bed, mostly awake, but resting all day - as she does everyday. Viewers can learn from the interviews and discussions, hear the hosts answer your questions, and of course see Dianna.

Pre-recorded interviews from experts ‚Äî

- Linda Tannenbaum, founder and CEO of the Open Medicine Foundation. Interviewed by Derek Muller from Veritasium.

- Dr. David Kaufman, an ME/CFS specialist. Interviewed by Vanessa Hill from BrainCraft.

- Dr. Raven Baxter, a science communicator. Interviewed by Kyle Kitzmiller.

- Dr. David Putrino, director of CoRE Center for Complex Illnesses Interviewed by Kyle Kitzmiller.

#MECFS #longcovid

Physics Girl Livestream, Saturday, July 6th 2024.

This Saturday we will be live-streaming a day in Dianna‚Äôs life, showing what it‚Äôs like for her suffering from ME/CFS. 
The Livestream will be viewable on the PhysicsGirl channel on Youtube from 6:45A.M. (PT. Pacific Time) to 6:00P.M. (PT).
It will be co-hosted by Ian Hecox and Simone Giertz, and will include pre-recorded expert interviews and in depth discussions of what Dianna is going through. 

Dianna will not be talking during the Livestream, she will be in bed, mostly awake, but resting all day - as she does everyday. Viewers can learn from the interviews and discussions, hear Kyle, Simone and Ian answer your questions, and of course see Dianna.

All funds will be going to the Open Medicine Foundation (OMF), a non-profit research organization dedicated to finding effective treatments for ME/CFS. (https://www.omf.ngo/)

In one week Dianna is live-streaming a full day of her life to share what the experience is like for someone suffering from ME/CFS. Dianna and Kyle are raising money to support research and clinical trials for long COVID.

The live stream will take place Saturday, July 6th 2024, from 6:45 AM(PT) to 6:00 PM(PT).

The live stream will consist of seeing Dianna, and what she does every day as a person with long COVID, interspersed with QnA's for the audience to ask anything they want, and a series of interviews with experts in the industry helping us all better understand the disease.

We hope you join and help us raise awareness for those suffering from this disease. More details to come.

 #longcovid #MECFS

Dianna decided to shave her head to make it easier on herself for her journey with long COVID and ME/CFS. Many people struggling with this disease choose to do this if bed-bound for extended periods of time, like Dianna has been.
 Hopefully she can avoid crashes, and reduce the amount of energy it takes to wash and maintain her hair every week. Millions of people are suffering from this quiet and deadly disease.

 #MECFS #longcovid

This is what life is like for Dianna when she is AWAKE. This is what severe Long COVID and ME/CFS can look like. 

We made a small time-lapse of what it looks like in Dianna's room for a day. This is what she has been doing every day since January of 2023.

Many people think if she were in her room all day without anything to do, that she could maybe watching TV or reading books. But the mental toll ME/CFS takes disables her from being able to do anything fun that is mentally stimulating. She is awake, but unable to meaningfully interact or have many complex thoughts. 

Dianna gets a few meals a day, a few words exchanged with her husband Kyle, and not much else.

#mecfs #longCOVID #chronicfatigue

#mecfs is unimaginably isolating, especially for severe patients like Dianna. The disease just doesn‚Äôt make sense; even for me, it‚Äôs taken a year of caring for her every day to start to understand. 

To get a sense, Dianna has spent the last year and a half in her room, unable to watch tv or read a book or spend time with friends. 

She cannot walk or take care of herself. She can brush her teeth and feed herself, but not much more than that. We can cuddle and hold hands, but sometimes that‚Äôs too much for her. It‚Äôs so removed from normal life, and so much worse than you could ever imagine. 

It‚Äôs hard to share these things, because I fear people will blame me or blame her for not treating her properly, for not taking this medication or that supplement, or following such and such a protocol. Or worse yet, suggesting that all she needs is to get up and go for a walk. 

Even on this post, people will say those things. 

But there‚Äôs no consistent treatment or even diagnostics at this point. So, we are left alone, in pain, wondering if what we‚Äôre doing is right or wrong, if there‚Äôs something else we should have done a year ago that would have avoided all this. We try not to think like that, but it creeps in from time to time. 

If you are a physician, please consider getting involved in treating and researching #longcovid and #mecfs While Dianna is still very sick, her doctors and treatments ease her burden and give us hope. 

Written by Kyle, Dianna‚Äôs husband.

(Levi typing)
Dianna - "I know I need to be resting more...but...there's an eclipse!"

We got to help Dianna see the eclipse today. Yes, she had to explain to us how to do it as we cut holes in paper and shined it on the wall. Witnessing an astronomical event with Dianna while she whispered "That's so cool" felt very close to the old days. 

We've all been taking it MUCH easier here, slowly, and patiently, allowing Dianna to rest rest rest. Sharing the eclipse with Dianna for a moment of wonder and giggles was really special.

After a couple minutes it was time to rest again. And we are all being hopeful for the full recovery. There's more eclipses coming her way. Thank you everyone.

Update from Kyle: More of the same over here: boredom, suffering, and finding what joy we can. Nothing much has changed, we‚Äôre slowly making our way through treatments and hoping for the best each time. 

I want to try and post a bit more, keep you informed of what‚Äôs happening with Dianna. This really feels like an invisible disease- it consumes our lives but there‚Äôs very few tests to indicate anything is wrong, and treatment efficacy is random. 

But we want to do our part to keep this as visible as possible, show the reality of #longcovid and #mecfs Bring more urgency to finding a cure. Thanks everyone for all your support and kind words, they mean so much to us.

GIANT Rogue wave hits an oil platform

Rogue waves -  enormous, spontaneous surface waves in the open ocean - were once the tall tales of sailors. They are waves that reach 2-3x taller than the largest average waves in the area, reaching heights of 75 ‚Äì 100ft. With the help of a ESA satellite survey, the scientific community now accepts they happen frequently. What causes rogue waves?

Dianna is still very sick, and in bed. However, her channel has continued to grow and hang on in her absence. Dianna is not sure when she will get better, and we‚Äôve all been worried about the future of Physics Girl. Knowing the channel is reaching so many people is great news.

Hello everyone, this video was taken a couple weeks ago of Dianna cutting her hair again. Dianna still hasn‚Äôt gotten out of bed, and it‚Äôs been long enough that her hair has grown out again.

Health Update ‚Äî
For the past 2 or more months, Dianna has been dealing with a very heavy crash from her chronic fatigue sydrome. As we know, these crashes keep her physically restricted, but equally as painful is the brain fog she experiences from the mental fatigue. From what we understand working with her doctor, these crashes are to be expected, and expected to be long. So though it‚Äôs hard for all of us to stay positive when it seems like she‚Äôs barely getting better, it‚Äôs important to remember that long set backs are a part of the slow recovery.

I(Levi, Dianna‚Äôs editor) make Dianna‚Äôs day meals Monday through Friday and I have not seen her in months. I give the meals to Kyle and he takes them to her as she is too weak to respond to anyone. I tell this story just to illustrate what it‚Äôs like here and how it‚Äôs still a lot of Dianna laying down trying to stay quiet. Sometimes I leave and come back and it‚Äôs surreal to see that she‚Äôs still like this in the thick of the disease. The GOOD news is for about the past week or 2, Kyle has been telling me she‚Äôs feeling slightly better. They believe she is slowly moving out of this crash, and they are both feeling more hopeful.

Dianna‚Äôs mom visits as often as she can. And we often express to each other our gratitude for all the online support. These month long ‚Äúcrashes‚Äù or ‚Äúsetbacks‚Äù are a reminder of how slow and long this process is and how none of it would be doable without the help. Dianna is very saddened to imagine she may be like this for 5, or 10, or more years. But we all feel like at least she can have something of a shot at a normal life thanks to all the help received.

Thank you so much everyone. Stay tuned for another bigger health update on the Youtube channel soon. If you'd like to support Dianna during her recovery, you can do so at - patreon.com/physicsgirl

(Dianna's editor posting) Dianna is currently suffering from a multi-week crash. It's been over a year since she got sick and she will still crash from any minor mental or physical stress. These crashes are the result from her severe MCAS and ME/CFS.

I started helping Kyle and Dianna full-time here a couple months ago, and it's surreal to see her state. I think when you're not around it, it's easy for the time to pass, or to assume the time goes by relatively easy from her bedroom. But it doesn't. 

Dianna still doesn't consume anything that is potentially overstimulating for her mind. She doesn't watch movies, read books, or listen to music. She's able to speak more throughout the day than she used to, and she develops little funny sentences or short songs in her head. But other than that, you're looking at it. These pictures are the exact place she has been laying since January, unable to even get up and use the bathroom.

This disease is slow, very slow. Some weeks are worse than others...

Health Update from Dianna (posted by Kyle)

Thank you everyone so much for the kind messages and checking in. The support and love is overwhelming.¬†

I just don't know how to respond. I am...very sick.¬†

My brain works at 20% capacity a few minutes a day. I can barely move or talk. The rest of the time, I lie here with my eyes closed in a quiet dark room, no music, no reading, no phone. I count breaths, meditate, repeat mantras to soothe my fears. Sometimes I succeed.¬†

I have severe MCAS. (And severe MECFS, POTS, SIBO, and a lower gut infection, that have been diagnosed so far.) 

The MCAS is brutal. I get dizziness, nausea, and chest pain from everything. Every food I eat, fragrance I smell, organic cotton sheets that have been boiled with no detergent, all my meds (that are supposed to help MCAS). I can't wear clothes, I can't use toothpaste, Kyle has to boil hypoallergenic baby wipes so I can "bathe" without getting rashes. This disease is truly horrible.¬†

But we're still trying treatments. And I promise, I am hanging in there. I have the best support system I could imagine, you all included.¬†‚ù§¬†D

#longcovid #mecfs #mcas

Health update - Dianna now has a PICC line inserted into her arm. The PICC is used to help Dianna receive IV medications and fluids without having an adverse reaction to them. The PICC is threaded up the arm through a large blood vessel that extends into the chest.

(Dianna's editor) - It's great that there are solutions like this to help Dianna get what she needs to help her in her recovery. And she genuinely looks better than she did earlier in the year. I can interact with her for a couple minutes a couple times a day, as apposed to her and I exchanging only a couple words a month like we were in March. But, with all that said, she is still daily bed-ridden and has a long road ahead of her. Many people ask daily if there are any health updates, and unfortunately, it's a very long and slow process with not a lot of progress. I have started helping Kyle care-take for Dianna full time, and being here is very surreal. She is still very very sick, but we are staying hopeful. And none of it would be possible without the online support. I'll give more updates whenever I can. Thanks everyone.

‚ÄúCrash Diet‚Äù for women published by Vogue in 1977.

The original recipe was published in the 1962 New York Times bestseller, ‚ÄúSex and the Single Girl: The Unmarried Woman‚Äôs Guide to Men‚Äù by Helen Gurley Brown.

The diet was just for two days and recommended to be done on the weekend because it would leave you ‚Äúfuzzy‚Äù. Brown said that the diet of only steak, eggs, wine and black coffee would help shed 5 pounds.

Office life before the invention of AutoCAD and other drafting softwares.

Prior to the release of AutoCAD in 1982, engineering drawings were all done by hand using different grade pencils, erasers, T-squares and set squares.

Even after all the manual labor, if a change was required, the engineers and toolmakers had to start from scratch and make the sketches all over again. Nowadays, architecture designers and other drafters are mainly just clicking their mouse and keyboard and not hunched over on a giant desk wondering if any changes will be made to their final drafts.

#autocad

This is Rube Waddell, an American baseball player (from the early 1900s) whose life story bewilders me to no end.

In the middle of a game, Waddell would disappear to chase fire trucks. He was easily distracted, so opposing fans would bring puppies, which would have Waddell running over to play with them.

American sportswriter and baseball historian Lee Allen wrote that in 1903, Waddell was ‚Äúsleeping in a firehouse at Camden, New Jersey, and ended it tending bar in a saloon in Wheeling, West Virginia. In between those events, he won 22 games for the Philadelphia Athletics, [...] toured the nation in a melodrama called The Stain of Guilt, courted, married, and became separated from May Wynne Skinner of Lynn, Massachusetts, saved a woman from drowning, accidentally shot a friend through the hand, and was bitten by a lion.‚Äù

It should be noted that Waddell was incapable of memorizing his lines for his part in The Stain of Guilt, so he was allowed to improvise his lines in every show. The play went on to critical acclaim.

In 1905, Waddell shared a room with baseball catcher Ossee Schreckengost who refused to continue sharing the room unless there was a clause in Waddell‚Äôs contract that forbade him from eating crackers in bed. It should be noted that it was common for players to share the same bed in hotel rooms while on the road. That same year, Waddell missed the World Series after injuring his shoulder while trying to destroy a straw hat.

However, he went on to win a Triple Crown in pitching. If the Cy Young award had existed during this time, Waddell would have won it over Cy Young himself.

He died of tuberculosis at the age of 37 on April Fool‚Äôs Day, 1914.

#baseball

A pair of hammerhead sharks depicted in the ‚ÄúOki National Products Illustration Notes‚Äù during the Edo Period in Japan, 1735.

I love how this illustration appears to be remarkably modern and cartoon-like, despite it being nearly 300 years old. I guess the Japanese always had a knack for drawing cute animals even way back then‚Ä¶

One cool fact about hammerhead sharks is that no fatal attacks against humans have ever been recorded. They also travel in large groups of up to 500 sharks, usually in the summer months as they migrate to find cooler waters. As for its weird head shape, the hammerhead has evolved to be better at sensing its environment, however the drawback is that they are equipped with smaller mouths, making them less effective at killing their prey.

The man on the left is Danish astronomer Tycho Brahe (1546-1601).

The fake nose (made of bronze) on the right is what he wore after he lost his real nose in a sword duel with his cousin Manderup Parsberg.

They had gotten into a drunken quarrel over who was the better mathematician.

On special occasions, Brahe would swap out the bronze nose for a silver or gold one.

#math

Statue of David encased in brick to prevent damage from bombs during World War 2.

An interesting fact about the Statue of David that I always like to share is that it was made from a flawed piece of marble that had already been rejected by two artists because of its poor quality.

The marble was called ‚ÄúThe Monster‚Äù and no one wanted to work with it. It remained abandoned and weathered by the elements for a quarter of a century.

In the summer of 1501, a 26-year-old sculptor by the name of Michelangelo decided to make use of it. In just three years, Michelangelo would complete what would become the world‚Äôs most famous statue.

This is Shavarsh Karapetyan, a retired Armenian swimmer.‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£‚Å£
In 1976, he had just completed a 26 km (16 mile) run when he heard a loud crash. A trolleybus had lost control and had fallen into a reservoir. It was 25 meters (80 ft) off shore and had sunk to a depth of 10 meters (33 ft).‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£‚Å£
Karapetyan immediately dived into the sewage-infested waters and managed to kick the back window of the trolleybus with his legs, despite zero visibility from the silt that had risen from the bottom. Of the 92 passengers onboard, Karapetyan pulled out 46 people. 20 of whom survived.‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£‚Å£
The combination of cold water and the multiple lacerations from glass shards led him to be hospitalized for 45 days. He developed pneumonia and sepsis. While he was able to recover, damage to his lungs prevented him from continuing his career as a swimmer.‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£‚Å£
‚ÄúI knew that I could only save so many lives, I was afraid to make a mistake. It was so dark down there that I could barely see anything. One of my dives, I accidentally grabbed a seat instead of a passenger. I could have saved a life instead. That seat still haunts me in my nightmares,‚Äù he said.‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£‚Å£
In 1985, Karapetyan came upon a burning building with trapped people inside. He rushed in and began pulling people out. He was badly burnt and had to once again be hospitalized.‚Å£‚Å£
‚Å£‚Å£
Later in life, he moved to Moscow and founded a shoe company called ‚ÄúSecond Breath‚Äù. He is still alive today and continues to run his business.

Kamala Harris‚Äô parents

I‚Äôll admit, I didn‚Äôt really know much about Kamala‚Äôs backstory, so I did some digging and here‚Äôs what I learned.

Her father, Donald J. Harris, was born in Jamaica and came to the U.S. to get his Phd in Economics. He served as a professor at Stanford University from 1972 to 1988. He is best known for his post-Keynesian ideas on economic growth. 

Her mother, Shamala Gopalan, hailed from India and came to Berkeley to study nutrition and endocrinology. She received her PhD in 1964. Her research focused on trying to find a cure for breast cancer. 

After 8 years of marriage, Kamala‚Äôs parents got a divorce. In her memoir, Kamala wrote, ‚ÄúIt was hard on both of them. I think, for my mother, the divorce represented a kind of failure she had never considered.‚Äù After a fierce custody battle, Kamala and her sister, Maya, were raised mostly be their mother. 

‚ÄúMy mother, who raised me and my sister, was a proud woman. She was a brown woman. She was a woman with a heavy accent. She was a woman who, many times, people would overlook her or not take her seriously. Or because of her accent, assume things about her intelligence. Now, every time my mother proved them wrong.‚Äù

Weekends and summers were spent with their father. They would take trips to Jamaica where they learned the history and culture through music and food. Her father recalls one of their trip to Jamaica in 1970: 

‚ÄúWe trudged through the cow dung and rusted iron gates, up-hill and down-hill, along narrow unkempt paths, to the very end of the family property, all in my eagerness to show to the girls the terrain over which I had wandered daily for hours as a boy‚Ä¶

Upon reaching the top of a little hill that opened much of that terrain to our full view, Kamala, ever the adventurous and assertive one, suddenly broke from the pack, leaving behind Maya the more cautious one, and took off like a gazelle in Serengeti, leaping over rocks and shrubs and fallen branches, in utter joy and unleashed curiosity to explore that same enticing terrain.‚Äú
