‚ÅâÔ∏è FAQ ‚ÅâÔ∏è

‚ùì Where can I get a timer video?
üí¨ Canva only has shorter timer videos in their element library (30-60 seconds) so I suggest inserting in your own video file. I have a set of timer videos that includes 1, 2, 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, and 30 minute timers in my TPT store if you need some (link above).

‚ùì Can I use a YouTube video as a timer?
üí¨ Yes, but it won‚Äôt play automatically. If you want to use a YouTube video, I suggest searching for an ‚Äúinterval timer‚Äù that will replay the same time frame over and over so you only have to hit play once. But, you wouldn‚Äôt be able to use a transition/clean up slide.

‚ùì Can I create these in Google Slides?
üí¨ Unfortunately, no‚Ä¶ Google Slides currently does not allow you to add timed transitions to slides so they won‚Äôt automatically rotation.

40 Before 40 üñ§

After turning 30 in October, I created what I'm calling a "40 Before 40" list with forty things I want to do in the next decade of my life before I turn 40. From travel experiences to philanthropy to skill development, my list is filled with all those little things that are easy to put off and tell yourself you'll get to "someday" but never end up doing if you're not intentional (which is my word for 2024).

üß† Super cool math techniques from @shelleygrayteaching! üß†

Shelley explains why promoting critical thinking is essential: 

"Are your students thinking in your math class? I mean REALLY thinking?

A worksheet with correct answers can mean that the student is good at repeating a procedure or memorizing, but it does not mean that they deeply understand a concept and are able to reason about it.

Here are some examples of simple shifts you can make to promote thinking and reasoning rather than mimicking."

November is National Adoption Awareness Month and I am so excited to share this news I‚Äôve been sitting on for the past two months. 
üíõ
After pouring my energy into creating and sharing content on IG for years, stepping back from this platform has been an incredible gift to myself. I am so happy to be working in a school with amazing people, continuing to support institutions and individuals with their ongoing DEI and ABAR work, and grow in my writing practice. It has been so life-giving to be in community with people every day and see and feel the impact of this work. 
üíõ
At the end of one particularly amazing year teaching 3rd grade, my students gave me a collage of their thumbprints positioned like leaves around the image of a tree with the quote from Hamilton, ‚ÄúLegacy. What is a legacy? It‚Äôs planting¬†seeds in a garden¬†you never get to see.‚Äù¬†At this point in my life, my gaze has turned towards this idea of ‚Äúlegacy work.‚Äù What will I leave behind? What will my legacy be as an ancestor to adoptees, to Korean Americans, to Jews, to queer folks who come after me? 
üíõ
As today marks the first day of National Adoption Awareness Month, I‚Äôm so excited to share the creation of the Soon Ok Scholarship (named after my birth mother) with the @highlightsfound an organization that has played a huge role in my growth as a writer over the past few years and opened up an entirely new and beautiful community to me. The Soon Ok Scholarship provides funds for a Transracial Adoptee Storyteller to attend an online or in-person Highlights workshop or retreat of their choice. It is funded for the next five years, and in honor of this month I would love it if folks donated to ensure its longevity. 
üíõ
If you‚Äôre a transracial adoptee aspiring author or illustrator, please see the instructions on the 3rd slide to learn more. As a community, we have a multitude of experiences and stories to share, and I hope you do.

After years of researching and writing ‚ÄúWhat Jewish Looks Like,‚Äù its book birthday is finally here! Tomy dear friend and co-author @carolinepritchardwrites thank you for saying yes to collaborating on this project. I couldn‚Äôt have imagined a more amazing writing partner to share this adventure. To @irisgottlieb the most incredible illustrator, thank you for bringing this idea to life. To @lueditsbooks and the @harpercollins team, thank you for believing in and championing this book. 
‚ú°Ô∏è
When it comes to writing for children, all I want to do is create the kind of books that I wish I had when I was little. I love being Jewish. And still I spent far too long believing it when both Jewish and non-Jewish people said I didn‚Äôt ‚Äúlook‚Äù Jewish, questioned my belonging, and asking for my receipts. I had no idea that such an expansive and beautifully diverse world existed within the Jewish community. It turns out, it was hidden in plain sight. I hope that this book contributes to everyone‚Äôs understanding of Jewish people, our history, resilience, and joy. L‚ÄôChaim!
‚ú°Ô∏è
To everyone who supported us throughout this process, preordered this book, and have shared it with their communities, thank you thank you thank you!
‚ú°Ô∏è

Hi and welcome to the 15k new folx to this page over the past few weeks! I wanted to introduce myself with a candid photo that shows me as a person, not a resource. Back when I started this IG account, it was just a place for me to post about my work, books, and meet other like minded teachers. If you had told me when I made my first post what this page would become, I never would have believed you. The posts on this page are both resources and evidence of my evolution as a thinker. There is language and content in my account that I no longer use or believe, but I keep it up because I think transparency of this work is important. I‚Äôve been working on non-violent communication for the past year in therapy, and it‚Äôs important that I share some personal agreements for myself, and what that means for y‚Äôall and I interact. Please swipe to read, and I‚Äôm happy you‚Äôre here! 
.
üíõMy name is Liz Kleinrock (she/her).
üíõAt the core of my work, I am a teacher. I‚Äôm here for dismantling white supremacy,¬†joy, and liberation.
üíõI‚Äôm a transracial adoptee. I was born in South Korea, and grew up in DC in an Ashkenazi Jewish family. I identify as Korean American and East Asian American.
üíõI am bisexual.
üíõI taught in California for about ten years (grades 1-5), and recently moved back to DC where I now teach 6th grade.
üíõI have 2 adorable and antisocial bunnies. 
üíõI like horror films, fly fishing, and reading outside.
üíõI dislike olives and being late.
üíõI wrote a book! It comes out in May!
.
Please read my ‚Äúnew folx‚Äù highlight in my profile, and free to drop a comment and introduce yourself. I‚Äôm excited to meet y‚Äôall, and hope y‚Äôall are committed to this work for the long haul.

You know those people who are just really, incredibly nice? You know how sometimes those really, incredibly nice people are also really, incredibly brilliant, talented, and committed to making the world a better place? Well that's @teachandtransform. It was such a delight to hang out, chat, and take some fabulous photos with her recently!

I was at the Texas Library Conference earlier this year and saw the one and only Ruth Behar signing copies of Across So Many Seas. I walked to the end of her signing line that wound damn near around the convention center and practiced what I‚Äôd say. ‚ÄúHi Ruth. My name is Caroline and your work has made such an impact in my life. My friend Liz and I have spent the past few years working on a middle grade biography collection that explores the diversity of Jewish peoplehood, and we‚Äôre honored to include you as one of those heroes. I‚Äôm grateful for the chance to meet you face to face after studying and writing about your work!‚Äù

When it was finally my turn, I stepped up to the table where Ruth faced me with a kind smile and raised pen. I then gracefully said the following before shoving my phone with the book‚Äôs cover in her face:

‚ÄúHi! Hero, you are! In our book! See!‚Äù 

Thank you, @ruthbeharauthor, for your patience. And thank you for your beautiful words about our book, which appeared in Andrew Esensen‚Äôs @jewishnews_sf article ‚Äú‚ÄòWhat Jewish Looks Like‚Äô: Children‚Äôs book highlights 36 diverse ‚Äòheroes‚Äô‚Äù 

WHAT JEWISH LOOKS LIKE releases in three weeks!!! Preorder from @politicsprose and we‚Äôll send you a signed copy and some delightful swag!

Liz and I are over the moon to feature the revolutionary Judy Heumann as one of the 36 heroes in our upcoming anthology WHAT JEWISH LOOKS LIKE. And we are incredibly excited to share that if you preorder the book online from @politicsandprose in DC, we‚Äôll include a signed, personalized copy along with a sticker featuring @irisgottlieb‚Äôs graphic from the book with Judy‚Äôs words!

When I think about my most aspirational understanding of what it means to look or be Jewish, it‚Äôs the very idea Judy describes here. Her carefully selected words‚Äî joining together, strategizing, sharing‚Äî are at the heart of what is required of us to move in the direction of meaningful solidarity and change. It‚Äôs a reminder that whenever I feel angry or hopeless or insufficient in the face of so much suffering in the world, the answer is turning towards one another instead of isolating inward. 

Swipe for specifics around the book swag and let us know if you have any questions. WHAT JEWISH LOOKS LIKE is out in the world in less than a month!!!

It‚Äôs been almost a month since I returned from a month Korea. I‚Äôve been so incredibly fortunate to have traveled back to my homeland for the past three years, all for different reasons and with different organizations. This summer it was all about @teachwithlove üíõ
üá∞üá∑
@teachwithlove is a BIPOC owned and operated International Education Program (NOT a trip and NOT a vacation!) Using the Teach with L.O.V.E. framework, we‚Äôre ‚ÄúLifting Others‚Äô Voices EVERYDAY.‚Äù One of the many things I love about this company is that funds from these professional development international programs go right back into the community to support leadership and learning for students of color. 
üá∞üá∑
It was an honor to co-lead this week long adventure with the brilliant @tainabenitez.co , just as much as it was an incredible learning experience. While my work has focused on antibias and anti racist practices, Taina schooled me on cultural intelligence which is such a powerful way to understand the different ways we behave, interact, and communicate with each other.
üá∞üá∑
Over this week, our group of educators came together to apply this framework to their own learning in a different cultural context. Working with local specialists (love to Sunny and Howard!) we learned on site at museums, Yonsei University, historical locations ranging from Gyeongbukgong Palace to the DMZ.
üá∞üá∑
The next TWL program in Korea is coming DECEMBER 2025!!! (For all the Christmas celebrating folks don‚Äôt worry we start after Xmas.) We have new locations for on-site learning in our itinerary, AND we get to walk around in the snow and pretend we‚Äôre Yoonsang and Yoojjn a la Winter Sonata.
üá∞üá∑
Go to teachwithlove.com to sign up and spend your winter break with us!

Another revolution around the sun. This past year has been one of transition, growth, tumult, and grounding. Experienced the release of 2 picture books, found a community in a new school that I love, entered into an administrator role, moved, and divested from putting so much time and energy into social media in order to cultivate the relationships and work I care so much about. I am beyond grateful to my partner, family, and friends for holding it down. I love yall so much!!

For my entire life growing up Korean and Jewish, I (Liz) yearned to see myself represented in the world. To this day, folks often react, ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt look Jewish‚Äù when they learn that I am, indeed, a Jew. Confronting these stereotypes was exhausting, and I spent far too much energy defending my identity as a kid. So a few years ago I texted my dear friend and talented author Caroline the idea of co-creating a book where children throughout the multiracial, multiethnic, and multicultural Jewish community would not just see themselves in its pages, but also deepen their own understanding of Jewish peoplehood. When I (Caroline) received Liz‚Äôs text back in 2021, I was buzzing. I wondered what it would have meant as a child to read a book like the one Liz was suggesting, and what it could mean for kids today. 

Today, we are very proud to share the cover of WHAT JEWISH LOOKS LIKE, a collection of short biographies of 36 Jewish heroes, changemakers, and creatives. Whether a Cochin Jew taking the spotlight in India‚Äôs silent film industry, a trailblazing Iranian American teenage Paralympian, or an Italian neuroembryologist who fled the Nazis while secretly pursuing Nobel-prize winning discoveries, these figures are diverse in identity and experience while bound together through a shared commitment to Jewish values. Our deep hope is that this book challenges misconceptions and creates opportunities for both learning and unlearning. 

Thank you to @lueditsbook at @harpercollins @harperkids for your unrelenting vision (and unmatched patience), @jstempellobell for your artistic magic, and our agents gknowlton58 and Emily Sylvan Kim for advocating at every turn. And @irisgottlieb ? We don‚Äôt know how you did it. This book sings because of you .We‚Äôre incredibly grateful to our extended village, old and new, for pushing us, at times arguing with us (two Jews, three opinions‚Ä¶), and helping shape this book to what it is today. And a huge thank you to @jewishbookcouncil for hosting the cover reveal! 

And with that, preorders are officially LIVE! Please check it out online anywhere books are sold for a more detailed description ‚ù§Ô∏è OUT 9/24/24 
#jewishamericanheritagemonth #kidlit

Today is the birthday of ‚ÄúEyes That Weave the World‚Äôs Wonders.‚Äù 
A dear friend of mine used to always say, ‚ÄúBe the person you needed when you were younger.‚Äù This book is a love letter to my younger self. For the moments when I felt out of place in my family, or when I wasn‚Äôt sure what questions I wanted to ask, or how to ask them, and when I felt like the only one.
.
This is my story (as you can see from the photos on each illustrated page.) It might not be for everyone. It might disappoint adoptees who have had vastly different experiences than mine and are hoping to see themselves reflected here. I desperately wish I could create something that would meet all of our needs.
.
Sharing these snapshots of my journey doesn‚Äôt mean I‚Äôm not hurting, doesn‚Äôt mean I don‚Äôt hold onto trauma, doesn‚Äôt mean I don‚Äôt think of my birth family every day, and doesn‚Äôt mean that I‚Äôm healed. I know I am all of these things- and so much more. I don‚Äôt want these things to solely define me. Writing this book while engaging in the search for my birth parents has been cathartic, and changed the way I see myself and the world.
.
Dear @joannahowrites thank you for being a partner to me on this adventure. As happy as I am that today we can share this book with the world, I‚Äôm also sad that it‚Äôs over! And @dunghanhho, you are brilliant. Thank you for making my childhood come to life.

This is the letter to readers from @teachandtransform at the beginning of Eyes that Weave the World's Wonders. 

This is one of so many different adoptee experiences that need to be told. It is the story of a young girl who is raised in a loving adoptive family and who wrestles with so many challenges and unanswered questions. It is her journey of understanding that she is the only person who is able to tell her own story, that she can weave the stories she knows into the eyelets and holes of stories she doesn't, that she has the power to define her own life. 

This book releases in just a few days on Tuesday, Jan 23! Preorder today! We can't wait for you to hold it in your hands and actually get to read it and take in all of @dunghanhho's beautiful artwork.

I was adopted on the first night of Hanukkah, so it feels particularly fitting to share this today. This is the story of me and my family, and the ongoing evolution of my identity as a Korean American transracial adoptee. 
.
I‚Äôve been staring at the PDF of this book for months, but holding the hard copy in my hands hit in a powerfully different way. As soon as I opened it and saw @dunghanhho‚Äôs illustrations of my birth mother, I started crying and couldn‚Äôt stop. (Shout out to @tudgie for answering my late night hysterical FaceTime call and the TRA PoCC crew for holding it down.)
.
If you‚Äôve never seen yourself represented in a book, sometimes you have to write it yourself. I‚Äôm so grateful for the friendship and partnership of @joannahowrites for sharing her platform and inviting me in to tell my story. I‚Äôm so proud of this book and can‚Äôt wait for everyone to see it.
.
‚ÄúEyes That Weave The World‚Äôs Wonders‚Äù is out on January 23rd. Please please please preorder! (Link in my bio) I hope you love it as much as I do.
.

Eep! Today after school I went to visit ‚ÄúCome and Join Us‚Äù on the shelves of @eastcitybookshop! What a wonderfully surreal experience! ü•∞

Community > everything else ü•∞
Thank you so much to everyone who came out to celebrate my debut picture book launch and @christianirabien‚Äôs preview of @amparofondita! In a world full of chaos and turmoil, never underestimate the life giving energy of being around people you love.

It‚Äôs hard to celebrate when there is so much pain and turmoil in the world, and at the same time it‚Äôs moments like this where we need to embrace moments of joy to keep us from spiraling into despair. Today is my first ever picture book birthday, something I‚Äôve dreamed about for years and wasn‚Äôt sure would ever come true.
üìö
‚ÄúCome and Join Us!‚Äù is based on the series of posts I‚Äôve shared over the past years about dismantling the hierarchy of holidays, especially how they‚Äôre taught in schools. ‚ÄúThe holiday season‚Äù is actually year round, because there are so many celebrations happening every month! It was my intention to include holidays and communities that are often overlooked, and to affirm these identities and traditions. Thank you so much to the folks I interviewed and the multiple sensitivity readers who shared so much of themselves!

Today was a very tough day - actually I don‚Äôt even know if tough is the right word.  Sadness. Confusion. Fear.  Exhaustion. I guess saying my heart is heavy goes further to capture it all.

All of this while having to show up at school bright and early and put on a game face to make it a good day for my 5 and 6 year olds because they deserve it and they are the future after all.  That was probably what was the hardest‚Ä¶ to not have time to really process how I feel personally and the fear I feel for what it may mean for our family. I don‚Äôt know that anyone not in our shoes can truly understand what gay families are feeling right now because it truly sucks. 

I want to be hopeful that things will be OK and that good things are coming, and I know eventually I‚Äôll be able to find and focus on the positives but I‚Äôm just not there - and if you‚Äôre not either that‚Äôs OK.

October: the month of report cards, conferences, assessments, first round of book clubs, Trunk or Treat, Halloween fun, and all of the other regular teaching expectations. So happy to be moving into a slightly less busy month! üòÖ

My favorite part of the month was finishing our ‚ÄúThe Wild Robot‚Äù novel study and getting to watch the movie with my class. If you haven‚Äôt seen the movie, I highly recommend it! It‚Äôs quite different from the book, but still amazing nonetheless! üå≥ü§ñ

My favorite way to review before an assessment: Deal or No Deal! I saw @thehungryteacher8th use this years ago and I‚Äôve been using it ever since!

At the beginning of the game, each group selects one case. They keep this case and will be allowed to open it at the end IF they are working well together and answering the questions correctly. 

We eliminate cases along the way just like the show does, but they‚Äôre not offered any ‚Äúdeal‚Äù to get out of the game early. üôÉ We answer a few questions (one at a time) then each group selects one case to eliminate. We do a few rounds of this and I check with groups as they‚Äôre working. After several rounds of this, I will give them the option to stick with the case they originally chose or swap it out with one of the cases that are still remaining. Whatever is in their case is given to each group member. Because our fifth grade uses a house system, most of the cases have points behind them. I also have things like lunch with teacher, stickers, candy, and a spin from our class wheel. Before I used the house system, I just used points and the group with the most points won a certain thing (i.e. lunch, classwork pass, candy, etc). This is always a hit with the fifth graders. üòÑ
September so far üñ§

Every Wednesday we have Class Meeting. This is a time when we highlight positive things we see in others, share our own accomplishments, ask questions, voice concerns, or make suggestions. It‚Äôs always one of my favorite moments in our room each week. This usually takes around twenty minutes. 

We are working on how to write a meaningful kudos/compliment for our classmates; something genuine and more thoughtful than just ‚ÄúKudos to ___ for being nice.‚Äù Today I gave each of them a compliment I wrote about them so they could see what the expectation is moving forward‚Ä¶ along with letting them see I am very thankful I get to be their teacher this year. üñ§

Picture Day display idea üí° It‚Äôs so neat getting to see our staff when they were students themselves! Zoom in a bit and you can spy myself and @misswestbest in there! (PS this is not our entire staff and participation was not mandatory.) You can swipe to see the letter I sent out to staff. üôÇ
This transformation was so much more work than year one, but I‚Äôm so thankful we have renovated rooms with new furniture! Relieved it‚Äôs all DONE!

We end our school year with a special day dedicated to every student in our class. Today was the last day of school and my students genuinely surprised me by giving me my very own ‚ÄúMrs. Root Day,‚Äù paired with a poster they secretly made. Kids are just the best. üíõ

Five student days left so we‚Äôre cramming in all the EOY activities we can. This is always a huge hit! We use Google Slides + Classroom to complete these memes! I‚Äôll post a link to the template in my stories! 

(The second picture here is so wildly accurate.)

A visual representation of why teachers need summer. üôÉ This year of teaching has been the most challenging year for me yet for a variety of reasons. To be clear, I LOVE working with students, and this is not meant to be interpreted as me being negative towards them whatsoever. Teaching just feels like *a lot* lately. I‚Äôve had moments this year when I feel like I am absolutely crushing things and feel so positive and happy with what I‚Äôm doing, but they‚Äôre quickly overshadowed by feelings of defeat and being utterly overwhelmed. Although I ‚Äúset boundaries‚Äù, ‚Äútake time for myself‚Äù, ‚Äúput my family first‚Äù, and ‚Äúremember my WHY‚Äù, it still feels draining; borderline impossible to keep up with it all. I know a lot of people feel this way, so if this sounds similar to what you‚Äôre going through please know I see you and empathize with you. Summer is just around the corner!

I‚Äôve been on the hunt for a good book to read with my class to help with their transition to middle school. I found this one the other day and it fits perfectly with what I‚Äôve been searching for! This time every year my students start getting really worried about leaving the elementary. The middle school feels scary and they‚Äôre nervous about leaving the comfort of familiarity. I think this book will lead to a perfect discussion about how although they feel sad to leave, it‚Äôs time and they are indeed ready. This ‚Äúend‚Äù leads to a new beginning, as all endings do. This book would be great to read with any grade level, not just fifth grade!

It‚Äôs officially time for our annual EOY countdown celebration! üóìÔ∏èüéâ Thank you to everyone sharing and tagging me in your countdowns; it‚Äôs really cool getting to see this happening in so many classrooms these days!

Each envelope contains one student‚Äôs name that will be revealed on the morning of the dates listed. I included a couple extra envelopes for group activities like extra recess, tech. time, etc. Once a student‚Äôs name is pulled after morning announcements, it becomes their special day! They receive perks like:
‚Ä¢picking their spot for the day and who they will sit with
‚Ä¢eating lunch in the classroom with a few friends of their choice 
‚Ä¢complimentary notes from their peers 
‚Ä¢a personalized letter from me 
‚Ä¢a special letter from their grownup(s)
‚Ä¢being line leader
‚Ä¢one sticker from our shop
‚Ä¢spinning our house wheel 
‚Ä¢selecting our class brain breaks 

I‚Äôve been doing this for years, and it truly never gets old! Such a wonderful way to close out the school year with each group of kids.

This is the last year I‚Äôll have my chalkboard, so I figured I should draw on it as much as I can while I still have it. Our rooms are being renovated this summer and I guess chalkboards are considered obsolete?? üòÖ

Pray for me‚Ä¶we‚Äôre trying groups tomorrow. Normally I ONLY have my desks in groups, but this year we have not been able to successfully do it. I despise how our desk rows take up our entire room, so I‚Äôm hoping some extra stars will inspire us to make these groups work. üôÉ

First day of 4th grade. How was my day? 

10/10 

So so great. It was busy and full + I‚Äôm so exhausted. But it‚Äôs the least-stressed I‚Äôve been at work in 5 years. It‚Äôs just what I‚Äôm supposed to be doing ü§ç

üí•Exciting Announcementüí•

I am going back to the classroom next year!‚ù§Ô∏è‚Äçüî•ü•π

The banner behind me reads- ‚ÄúRemember that you once dreamed of being where you are now.‚Äù

I started teaching in 2007 and quickly realized teaching was my true passion. I spent 11 years working at various schools- both private, public, and overseas in Cairo, Egypt. Through those years I have taught Pre-K, TK, K, 1st, 2nd, 4th, & 5th. 

In my 3rd year of teaching I started @applesandabcs to share ideas and resources with teachers all over. Five years ago I had the opportunity to run @applesandabcs full time while I stayed at home with my kids. My time shifted from pouring into students to pouring into teachers. About a year ago, I felt this change inside me and I knew it was time to go back to the classroom. It was actually after presenting at my first @getyourteachon conference that I knew I was being called back to my first love- teaching the students. It has taken a year of praying and waiting to see if going back to the classroom would be what is best for me and my family.

I am THRILLED to announce that I will be teaching full time next year. The grade level announcement will need to wait until the end of August, but I can‚Äôt wait to share that with you soon. ü§ó I will still be present here online, and I would love to take you along with me on my journey back to the classroom. ‚ù§Ô∏è‚Äçüî•

ü™©Classroom Mini-Tourü™©
I wanted to create a space that was bright, yet calm at the same time. I didn‚Äôt necessarily want a theme, so I went with bright colors but tied the boards together with black and white borders that MATCH MY RUG!

The space is still a work in progress. I am still moving things around every day. I have tons of drawers that only have a post-it note labels, but the main thing I am working on right now is focusing on classroom management and building a classroom community. All the labeling can wait.

‚ù§Ô∏è‚Äçüî• My Why ‚ù§Ô∏è‚Äçüî•
Running @applesandabcs full time I wasn‚Äôt able to maintain a healthy work-life balance. A lot of educators who left the classroom to run their own business are able to keep work boundaries, but for me it was a constant struggle. This pic is Sloane coming to find find me, already in her pj‚Äôs with toothbrush in hand. I was cooped up in my office, trying to beat some @applesandabcs deadline.

Now I‚Äôm back in the classroom and a still have 900 deadlines and 900 plates spinning. But this time I have in-person coworkers and students that are starting to feel like family. I still find myself having to work at night here and there, but it really is a means to an end until I finally feel settled in my new job.

The true goal is to only be working while we are all in school. Of course there will be outlying weeks/ days‚Ä¶ but overall, I want work to be clearly defined. I‚Äôm giving myself about four more weeks to truly find balance, but I‚Äôm praying it comes quicker than that.

‚ú®BTS Night 2024‚ú®
Clear Eyes, Full Hearts
My favorite thing in my classroom: a ü™© diffuser with a dupe of the @anthropologie ‚ÄúVolcano‚Äù scent. ‚ú®

This week we read Collaboration Station by @lifebetweensummers (and I got major points for saying I know her ü§£). We discussed what it looks like to work in partners or small groups and what teamwork characteristics we want in a parter. Then we partnered up and I gave them the challenge to build a creature out of @mywikkistix that represented them as a pair. They needed to discuss what they had in common, decide on their creation, and build it! Such a fun and simple team building activity!

Next year I‚Äôll be teaching‚Ä¶.

‚ú®4th grade!!!‚ú®

I‚Äôm in all my feels over teaching 4th grade next year, but I know it‚Äôs exactly where I‚Äôm supposed to be.

What does that mean for sharing here? I‚Äôll still be sharing resources I‚Äôve made over the years for primary while also taking you on the journey back to the classroom to teach 4th! Let‚Äôs get this party started!!! ü•≥ü•≥ü•≥

I need your help with how I want to implement ‚Äúfantastic flamingos‚Äù in my class. Here are my ideas so far. Tell me what you think in the comments below! 

I want to write a number on each flamingo that is assigned to each student. At the beginning of the day I‚Äôll pick a flamingo and they will be the ‚Äúfantastic flamingo‚Äù for the day. At the end of the day we will take a couple of moments to give that student verbal ‚Äúshout outs‚Äù of what we noticed or were impressed by them during the day, with the whole intention of building community and looking for ways to give that student compliments. 

But I was also thinking about maybe making that student the designated/main helper for the day? So it would almost be tied into one of our classroom jobs. It could could be a two for one situation, where they are the main helper AND they get peer shout outs at the end of the day. 

What do you think?

Light invites wonder. This week, we observed how children interacted with coloured acrylic on the light table, layering and arranging them to explore their interactions. At my #reggioinspired preschool, light is a material that sparks dialogue, imagination, and curiosity. #CuriosityInAction #DialogueWithLight #playislearning #bangkokpreschool
#thonglor
#playislearning #thonglor #bangkokpreschool

Sand on a tuff tray with a "boutique" of creatures. This little one decided she would tell a story of a predator trying to eat the eggs of a mama lizard (out of a selection of many different creatures and materials). Mama lizard fought back to defend her babies and sent the predator to the hospital! 

"Boutiquing" at our centre means that children have choice and agency over what and how they play. We intentionally place shelving or baskets around the centre with 'beautifu stuff' and interesting items for children to freely select and to take to wherever their imagination goes.

 #playbasedkindergarten #playislearning #outdoorpedagogy #thonglor #curiouskind

From snails, soil, leaves to feathers...the children are looking closely with all of their senses and communicating, sometimes without words, their connection to the natural world. "Children are born naturalists. They explore the world with all of their senses, experiment in the environment, and communicate their discoveries to those around them." - The Audubon Nature Preschool. #natureinspired #natureplay #reggioinspired #reggiobangkok #thonglor

"If you can't live in the land you love, love the land you're in."
Richard Louv, Last Child in the Woods

Everyday #natureplay . Maybe I cannot be "home", but, I get to "love the land" I am immersing in everyday.

 #natureinspired #reggiobangkok #thonglor #thailand

"Then you and he can look for the answers, sharing the wonder, curiosity, pain ‚Äì everything. It is not the answers that are important, it is the process ‚Äì that you and he search together." The wise words of Professor Rinaldi,  President of Fondazione Reggio Children - Centro Loris Malaguzzi.

As we launch our #reggioinspired
project experiences and the children start asking questions about their world, this quote reminds me to honour their theories with thoughtful responses and to invite co-researching and discovering together. #thonglor #bangkokkindergarten #bangkokpreschool

I can't help but be in awe at what an open-ended material (such as playdough) can do for calm, focus, and imagination. #playislearning #playbasedkindergarten #playistheway #curiouskind #thonglor #reggiobangkok #reggioinspired

Clay, cardboard, and sticks. Simple and reusable materials that have high affordance values- this means they can be ANYTHING a child can imagine, create, and transform (if we give them the time, freedom and space to explore). The use of these types of materials are an integral part of my practice as an early child educator. #reggioinspired #reggiobangkok #playislearning #bangkokpreschool #thonglor

It has been truly magical this year to witness the power of mark-making in two- and three-year-old emerging writers. Offering them various tools (chalk, paint, markers) and surfaces (acrylic, cardboard, paper) brought their creativity to life. In our Reggio-inspired setting, graphic representations are fundamental for children to communicate and express their thoughts, emotions, and stories. These visual expressions provide us with a glimpse into the children's inner worlds, their unique perspectives, and their interactions with the environment. #playistheway #playislearning #bangkok #reggioinspired #reggiobangkok #bangkokpreschool #bangkokkindergarten #thonglor #earlychildhoodcareeducation

Held nature

Let sand slip through their fingers

holes in clay

capable, unique. I am who I am.

Paint, flowers and four year olds: a beautiful combination. A simple provocation that led to a number of truly unique pieces. Bending, twisting, manipulating... Another open-ended material for #innovation and #creativeplay in my Early Childhood classroom. Like #clay, wire is malleable. Children's hands breathe life into this everyday object. Endless opportunities and explorations abound.  #wireexplorations
The #lightupmyplay with a #lighttable and #looseparts for exploring #identity. #openended #childledlearning

Outside, inside. The wonder of nature unfolded right before our eyes as we witnessed two little brown #bulbuls become a family of four. Simple wonders right outside our window that inspired #writing, #storytelling and love for the magic of the natural world. #earlychildhoodeducation  #reggioemilia

You‚Äôre my favorite boo and I‚Äôve got something fun for you‚Ä¶ üëª It‚Äôs time to get the Class Boo Gram prepped and ready!

Comment KINDNESS and I‚Äôll send you the link to this product that is a fun way to focus on spreading kindness throughout October! üëèüèº

What is a Class Kindness Gram?
This is a pass it on kindness challenge that you start with one student and let it spread throughout the entire class. You will display the kindness gram poster somewhere in your classroom and have a bin of kindness note sheets nearby. One student will begin by writing a kind note and doing something thoughtful for a peer and then leave the note on their desk or student mailbox. They will also color and attach the sticker to the poster showing who has received a class pumpkin gram. The person who received the gram will then pass it on and do the same for another classmate! ü©∑

This new product is available now in my TpT store! Comment Kindness and I‚Äôll send you the üîó

‚ú®üëª Hey BOO I‚Äôve got a DIY Halloween craft that is perfect for you! üëª‚ú®

Supplies Needed:
üß°Cheese cloth, fabric, or even tissues
üß°Plastic practice golf balls
üß°Yarn
üß°Black paper
üß°Scissors
üß°Hot glue
üß°Hole punch

Directions:
1. Begin by threading the yarn through the golf balls to tie a knot. Do this with all the golf balls you are using.
2. Cut 5-7 inch squares and layer 3 on top of each other.
3. Pinch in the center and cut a small hole. Then thread the yarn from the golf ball through the hole in the fabric stack.
4. Hole punch black eyes and hot glue onto the ghost.
5. Tie the ghosts onto a string of yarn that will hang across your bulletin board.

Enjoy your spooky ghost garland. Don‚Äôt forget to like and save this reel then tag your teacher boo in the comments!! üëªüß°üëª

Term 2 is MASSIVE! 

The assessments, the data gathering, the report writing, the parent teacher interviews‚Ä¶ but in amongst that one part is the excursions, the managing curriculum, still lesson planning, the whole school events, kids away with sickness, you‚Äôre sick/tired/burnt out, you‚Äôre covering lessons for other teachers‚Ä¶ term 2 is HARD! And sadly, no matter how many term 2s you‚Äôve already had, they don‚Äôt get alot easier! 

But focus on the positive! It‚Äôs nearly over. Reports are almost due, the assessments are all done, and it‚Äôs time to count down to our much deserved break! Stay focused on the end goal - sharing the positive outcomes your students have made this term, and getting some much needed REST for yourself. üñ§

#term2 #teacher #teacherlife #teachersofinstagram #teacherstruggles #reportwriting #teacherburnout #teachertired #tired #term2tired #tiredteacher #schoolholidays #positiveteacher

It‚Äôs report writing season! (And in my opinion, the worst time of the year!) 

Let‚Äôs face it, reports take up a huge amount of time! And most schools/departments have some pretty strict guidelines around what you can and can‚Äôt write on a report - which sometimes leaves you feeling like you haven‚Äôt said too much about the students ability, where they could really improve or how wonderful they are as a person. 

üåü The biggest thing to save time, is to write down things as you work through the term/semester. Have a spreadsheet/doc that has all your students names, and jot down a couple of points as the semester goes along. Even a word or two will help save time during the report writing process! 

üåü Keep your report comments in a word doc every semester - you‚Äôll thank yourself each time it comes to report writing for Year 9 Geography, or Year 6 Maths. The outcomes being assessed will be the same so you can use, and mould, your comments for your new class! 

But most importantly, don‚Äôt procrastinate on writing reports! Leaving it to the last minute will create a lot of undue stress and sleepless nights! Set your timeline and stick to it! You‚Äôll thank yourself! 

#reportwriting #teacher #reportwritingseason #teacherlife #teachertips #teachersofinstagram #instateacher #nswteachers #aussieteachers #aussieteachertribe #term2 #studentreport #reportwritingtips #firstyearteacheradvice

I always think about the many hats that teachers wear. Our job goes FAR beyond the planning and teaching lessons - the job that people outside of teaching think we do. We are reporters, investigators, nurses, psychologists, administrators, data entry clerks, data analysts, IT experts, and my favourite job, acting like I have the confidence to get up in front of people and make the lesson engaging! With all of these hats we wear, it‚Äôs no wonder teachers are burning out at a rapid rate. 

Imagine if we got paid for all of the roles that we did? üòÇ 

#teaching #teacher #teacherlife #teachergram #teachersofinstagram #teachertribe #teacherproblems #aussieteachers #aussieteachertribe #teacherburnoutisreal #teacherburnout #teachersfollowteachers

If I had a dollar for every time I was asked what makes a great teacher, I think I‚Äôd be rich! And it‚Äôs funny, that everyone‚Äôs answers are so different. 

So, what would your response be? What do YOU think makes a good teacher? 

From fellow teachers you will get very differing answers depending on what they value most in their own teaching, or in the teaching of their peers. Students will often give very similar responses if you ask them to give you an answer at the same time, however, if you ask them individually, it‚Äôs amazing what they really want. 

I did this with my class not too long before I went on leave. And it‚Äôs funny how the results didn‚Äôt shock me. They weren‚Äôt about getting them good marks, or about knowing the content, they were about being honest with them and genuinely showing that you care through listening and knowing who they are as people. 

Kids are humans too - and most of them just want to feel heard and valued. It‚Äôs amazing what you will get out of them if you give them what they need the most. 

#teachergram #goodteacher #aussieteachers #compassion #motivation #understanding #knowledge #teachertiptuesday #teachersofinstagram #teachertoolbox #preserviceteacher #newteacher #bestteacher #teacherlife

We always remind students that everyone has to start somewhere - that we can‚Äôt know everything and that we all have to start at the beginning‚Ä¶ so why don‚Äôt we remind ourselves of this in our own lives?

Even as teachers, we are forever learning. There is always going to be someone we can help, but there is always going to be another teacher who we look up too and who inspires us. We are forever growing and changing in both our personal and professional self! 

If you are sitting there wondering how to approach a certain part of teaching, reach out to someone more experienced in that area (or send us a DM!)

#newteacher #preserviceteacher #australianteacher #foreverlearning #teachergram #aussieteachers #aussieteachertribe #teachersupport #teachertoolbox #nswteachertribe #preserviceteachersaustralia #aussieteacher

At the start of a new term, it‚Äôs always helpful to set yourself some teaching goals to provide focus and direction for the term. And with so many preservice teachers doing placements this term, it‚Äôs critical to have focus or you‚Äôll try to do everything. 

Setting yourself goals can help you to stop trying to do everything in the classroom, and allow you to focus on the things you‚Äôve deemed important! 

Your goals may look like:
- differentiating work for ‚Äòstudent‚Äô 
- focusing on developing paragraph structure 
- collaboration to encourage team work skills 
- only one extra-curricular activity 

Having focus allows you to address the needs of your kids and to see progress. If we do something consistently, it promotes change and growth. And it makes it so much easier to assess progress. 

What are your goals/focus for Term 2? 

#preserviceteacher #preserviceteachersaustralia #teachergram #teachersofinstagram #teacherburnout #teachergoals #termtwo #teacherfocus #newteacher #beginningteacher #primaryteacher #secondaryteacher #nswteachers #aussieteachers #teacherssupportteachers

BEGINNING TEACHERS 

We know the first few years of teaching are tough! We know there is so much that your university degree doesn‚Äôt prepare you for! And we know that sometimes, there isn‚Äôt the support you need coming from your mentor or school. 

We want to know what have been your biggest challenges, where you needed support, and what you wished your university degree had prepared you for!

Send us a DM or comment below ‚¨áÔ∏è

With Term Two rapidly approaching, it‚Äôs a perfect time to reflect on what you are going to change from Term One. 

One great way of doing this is to set your goals and boundaries. What do you want to achieve in the classroom and for yourself? Where are you spending time that you feel isn‚Äôt serving you to make you happier or more productive? 

For our beginning teachers, you may need to put further boundaries in place to not take so much work home (delete your work email from your phone!!), or to give yourself free afternoons and a free Saturday and plan for the week on a Sunday. 

For pre-service teachers, you may be going into your placements or internship. This can be scary, stressful and overwhelming. Make sure you set a consistent routine (which includes a daily dose of exercise/downtime) to ensure you don‚Äôt get overworked, and feel like your drowning! And ask for help! Every teacher started somewhere and they want to help. Never feel like you‚Äôre in this alone ü§ç

Term Two is busy, and stressful. Do what you can now to ensure that it‚Äôs as smooth as possible!

I remember when I first started teaching, I was thrown in the deep end with two Year 12 classes. I had absolutely no idea what I was doing and I had 25 kids futures now riding on me being able to do my job without ever stepping foot in a classroom before. 

It was stressful, anxiety inducing, and definitely pushed me way out of my comfort zone. 

While I had some support, most of my first year (well, the first 5 years!) was me floundering, being a lesson ahead, and feeling like I was still on the same unknown path I‚Äôd been the year before. 

After that experience, it makes sense to me why so many teachers leave the profession in the first five years of teaching. And it makes me worry even more before universities are NOT providing the necessary training to ensure teachers are prepared when stepping foot into the classroom. 

After years and years now in the system, it‚Äôs time to do something about encouraging the right candidates to begin a teaching degree and for those pre-service and beginning teachers to get the help they require in the classroom! (And maybe even bringing back some of that passion for experienced teachers who are ready to leave!). 

Big things need to change! 
But for now, let‚Äôs start here‚Ä¶ 
Let‚Äôs bring the love for teaching back ü§ç

This year, I‚Äôm using Everyday Math as my core curriculum. It‚Äôs totally new to me, and so is teaching geometry at the beginning of the school year. I wanted to get a bit creative with teaching polygons and parallelograms, so when I found the parallelogram club (2nd picture), I knew I had to make it even broader! We learned about the very exclusive private polygon school, the quadrilateral class within it, and the ultra-exclusive parallelogram club. My 4th graders LOVED this, and it was the perfect visual for them (and also great for talking about how those poor outsiders felt üòâ)! If I had to do it again, I would have made my school larger so that I could fit the names of all the shapes in.

Hey Teach! ‚úåüèº

‚ú®Teaching is tough. Especially when you‚Äôre just starting out! We know you‚Äôre overwhelmed. We know you‚Äôre ‚Äòdone‚Äô. You‚Äôve given your all this year! Burnout is real but we really want to help!

‚ú®Maybe you‚Äôre a teacher candidate, maybe you‚Äôre in your first few years, maybe you‚Äôre a seasoned teacher who needs a few new ideas in your arsenal because of all the changes always happening. 

You‚Äôre in the right place!

‚úÖ Welcome to @theteacherpath! We are Tash and Kris, a couple of Bestie Teacher Moms who, through a lot of mentoring and supporting new teachers, occasional teachers and teacher candidates, have seen some consistent gaps where expectations are high but information hasn‚Äôt been shared.

Hey Teach ‚úåüèº ‚úèÔ∏è 

Tash and Kris here from @theteacherpath with another Tip Tuesday!

If you‚Äôre anything like us, some of those essential classroom items can dwindle‚Ä¶like a LOT‚Ä¶this time of year. Despite our best efforts, pencils can be a hot commodity! 

This funky contraption has been another game changer the last few years to help keep those pencils in one place. Students LOVE the novelty of it at first but really appreciate that in order to hit the button and get a pencil, that there must BE pencils in the container and are much more likely to return their pencils. 

One of our student jobs is to sharpen pencils and ensure that the container is full. If we are at those time of the year when pencils are getting pretty short, they can be replaced, of course, but this has slowed down the cases of missing pencils around the class! 

This straw dispenser can also be adjusted to dispense the larger Primary pencils as well as your regular HB. It‚Äôs been such a hit that we‚Äôve bought them for our own kids‚Äô teachers too!

Hey Teach! ‚úåüèº 

Tash and Kris from the Teacher Path here üí´ 

Come on a little tour to check out our classroom zen zone!

We can‚Äôt be ready to learn unless all of our needs are met. That‚Äôs a fact of life. If our students aren‚Äôt feeling comfortable, they won‚Äôt be prepared to learn. Sometimes a little reset helps. 

Giving students an opportunity to realize they need a moment to become ready is important and even though it may take 5 minutes out of their learning, if they don‚Äôt have that chance, it may result in far more than 5 minutes wasted! 

Simple little additions to the classroom and explicit instructions that students must follow when in the Zen Zone has made this a game changer for students who have struggled in the past with behaviours. 

Keep following the Teacher Path for more tips, tricks and every day strategies that we love to share! üòç

‚ÄºÔ∏èLet‚Äôs Talk Easy C.M‚ÄºÔ∏è
(Classroom Management) 

Hey Teach ‚úåüèº

Tash and Kris here from @theteacherpath 

‚ú® Classroom Management can be a daunting subject‚Ä¶ however over the years there has been a couple tools in our toolbox that we have kept consistent throughout the year. 

‚úîÔ∏è Timers (transitions and visuals) 
‚úîÔ∏è Doorbells! This is a great tool especially one you can incorporate different strategies like ‚ÄúKnock Knock‚Äù (teacher says) ‚ÄúWho‚Äôs There?‚Äù 
‚úîÔ∏è Rewards systems (these can get expensive and often time loose the stamina as the school year goes) 
 ‚ú®Desk Pets (super fun and you can add holiday theme items in them to surprise the kids) different accessories they can add add as a reward, maker station to get creative, or even a writing piece for language) 
‚ú® Stickers are always a huge hit! 
‚úîÔ∏è Non- Negotiable Tool that expectations are easily understood my a visual cue.
 ‚ú®For me it is my DUCK HAT‚Ä¶ when this hat is on 
  The students know that I am busy working with 
  Students (assessing, group work or 
  conferencing) 
‚ÄºÔ∏è My hat changes with the seasons, but it has been a lot of fun to implement and has the kids smiling üôÇ

Kerry Lee MacLean has produced some marvellous children‚Äôs storybooks regarding maeditation - some HILARIOUS enough to appeal to the little ones and others that are more about the ‚Äúwhy‚Äù than the ‚Äúhow‚Äù. ‚ÄòMoody Cow Meditates‚Äô is a book that uses humour to shows kids how to deal with upsetting situations and feelings of anger. ‚ÄòPeaceful Piggy Meditation‚Äô explores another range of emotions and shows kids how to deal with sadness and anxiety as well as the benefits to meditation in general! Another great book to help students be more mindful in their daily lives is ‚ÄúA World if Pausabilities‚Äù written by Frank J. Sileo and illustrated by Jennifer Zivoin. This book will show students that you don‚Äôt need to be sitting criss cross on a carpet with your eyes closed in order to be mindful. Rather, that mindfulness moments can happen even when you‚Äôre doing something as simple as taking a walk or brushing your teeth - all you need is a little pause(ability)! Definitely consider having a read aloud with this book or including it in your class library! Happy Teaching! ‚Ä¢

While we‚Äôre already on the topic, I‚Äôd like to introduce some more masterpieces, this time by both members of The Dream Team! The wellness series by @susanverde and @peterreynolds features some more fantastic storybooks that illustrate and articulate the concept of mindfulness. They are also written in a way that even a simple read aloud of these books would be able to help you build self-awareness, mindfulness and social-emotional learning among your students. ‚ÄúI Am Human‚Äù, ‚ÄúI Am Peace‚Äù, and ‚ÄúI Am Yoga‚Äù are all books that help students identify and embody concepts such as positive self-talk and empathy by first modelling it through the adorable watercolour characters that practically leap off the page! Susan Verde and Peter Reynolds are often referred to as the dream team when it comes to children‚Äôs literature regarding social-emotional learning. So, seeing as social emotional learning is an important component of mindfulness, today I present to you a few Storybooks by one half of ‚ÄòThe Dream Team‚Äô - Peter Reynolds! First off, ‚ÄúThe Dot‚Äù. This book takes readers on a journey with Vashti, the main character as she explores self-discovery, self-confidence, and creativity. Next, we have ‚ÄúIsh‚Äù. This award-winning storybook shows readers the value of being apart from the norm and thinking ‚Äòish-ly‚Äô. It also explains to readers that we must not let the opinion of others affect the things we like and dislike about ourselves. Then we have, ‚ÄúSky Colour‚Äù. Readers meet Marisol, who, when painting her school mural, finds she doesn‚Äôt have blue paint to make the sky. This book explores the creative thinker in all of us and different ways we find inspiration. Happy Teaching! ‚Ä¢

Today I‚Äôll be sharing a professional development resource for us teachers. Our profession is anything but static so it is imperative that we stay updated with the research in the field of education. This article was published in 2019 and authors Eric Chiang and Albert Sumell studied the effectiveness of mindfulness practices in the classroom. They found that with the implementation of mindfulness practices in school, there was an improvement in student performance. This just goes to show that not only can mindfulness practices help with students‚Äô social-emotional development, it can also impact their academic performance. There are also other studies produced that mention the impacts of mindfulness practices on reducing test anxiety if implement before assessments as well. It is always good for us to use literature to support (or disprove) the practices we employ in our classroom. Happy Teaching! ‚Ä¢

Have you ever wondered what it feels like to have ADHD? Understood.org has made this possible. Use the link in my bio to access a simulation that will allow you to experience the classroom through the eyes of a child with ADHD. Teaching students with ADHD can be a little difficult if you‚Äôve never done it before or if you aren‚Äôt well informed on what ADHD is. Author Shelley Murphy has written a tremendous piece that includes a summary of the internal and external characteristics of ADHD and is also jam-packed with strategies for supporting students who exhibit these characteristics. This piece is titled ‚ÄúFinding the Right Fit: Inclusive Strategies for Supporting Students With Characteristics of ADHD‚Äù. Essentially, ADHD stands for Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder. It entails certain qualities in the affected student that act as their strengths (such as higher levels of curiosity, creativity, empathy, enthusiasm, and energy) as well as some that pose challenges to their learning (such as inattention, impulsivity, and hyperactivity). Now it is one thing to be able to read that description of students with ADHD and it‚Äôs a WHOLE NEW thing to experience being in their shoes first hand. Only when we experience their struggle with the previously mentioned challenges first-hand are we able to truly cater to their learning needs. That‚Äôs why the simulation I mentioned earlier is so great. It really brings to life everything we read about ADHD and makes an impression on the way we conduct our classes. Happy teaching! ‚Ä¢

Not if they *want to*. This concept, brought to us by Ross Greene, is something we as educators need to recognize and internalize. Integrating this understanding into our teaching philosophy can reconceptualize how we perceive challenging behaviours. More often than not, students want to listen attentively during your lessons, they want to get along with their classmates, and they want to succeed in your class. The reason they exhibit challenging behaviours instead of this might be because they are lagging or lacking in the skills required to do so. In other words, if they have these skills, they *CAN* do well. Consider this; I may *want* to be a doctor, but I cannot do this because I am lacking the skills required. If I acquire these skills, I *CAN* be a doctor. Are you helping your students develop the skills they NEED so they CAN do well?. Happy Teaching!

I would like to share this wonderful resource for all my fellow educators out there looking for ways to incorporate the development of multimodal literacy in their own classrooms! The article that is mentioned in the second photo of this post (swipe left) is one that reiterates the importance of teaching multimodal literacy to the students of the 21st century. It is also a great resource particularly for junior-level teachers. Whenever a new teaching practice emerges, teachers find it hard to implement because it may be unfamiliar to them. This article is wonderful because it makes reference to the usefulness of graphic novels/comic books in facilitating multimodal literacy development in a fun way. The article summarizes three graphic novels that students in the past have responded well to and provides SPECIFIC ways in which these multimodal texts can be used to invoke an analytical lens in the students reading them. This could help you kickstart or revive the development of multimodal literacies in your students and really get them thinking! As well, you might want to have your students engage in the composition of their own graphic novels! (Swipe left again for sample work) Provide lots of colour mediums, paper, and as much creative freedom as you can spare, and watch the wheels turn! This article is sure to help you navigate the implementation of critical literacy and multimodal literacy practices in your classroom. It features an in-depth analysis of the need for multimodal literacy among the young learners of today. It also suggests different pedagogical approaches to multimodal literacy in the classroom such as the systemic functional approach which is explained in great detail throughout this text. As well, you might even be able to make use of some of the forms of literature that were used in the study portion of this article in your classroom! Be sure to read more about the rationale behind the selection of these pieces of literature and build your incorporation of multimodal literacy practices on this strong foundation. This book would serve as an impactful addition to your collection of teaching resources and tastefully compliments our discussions on the topic thus far. (Swipe left for the reference to this book!) As a history buff, I had an amazing time over the holidays in Vietnam and Cambodia where I floated in a sampan in the Mekong delta, shot an AK-47 at the Cu Chi Tunnels, slept in Halong bay (one of the 7 Wonders of the Natural World) and hung out at Angkor Wat.
Now I start my first-year teaching journey tomorrow at school and I‚Äôm excited to see what the year brings me ‚ú®
Armistice day was remembered at our school with everyone, including teaching staff and students, creating thousands of crosses to represent those who had fallen at the end of World War 1 üéñ

First casual day done and I finished my final assessment! Don‚Äôt know how I feel yet being a proper adult, but I can‚Äôt wait to see where it takes me! Thanks mum and dad for my cute graduation cap and owl charms üíïüë©üèº‚Äçüè´

Prac Day 25:

I‚ÄôM FINALLY FINISHED WITH PRAC! üéâüéâAND I NOW CAN BE EMPLOYMENT AS A CASUAL TEACHER! ‚ú®This is literally the weirdest feeling yet best day ever! This prac has been the best thing and now that I have completed this I can officially be left in a classroom by myself and not supervised üòÇüòÇ

I thought I would be a good chicken and help my supervisor mark the exams that my Year 8 class had just completed. Prac Day 21/22:
If you are wondering why I‚Äôm hiding in the storage room, it‚Äôs because my cold just doesn‚Äôt want to leave me and I feel so bad being noisy in the staff room üòÇ the pst few days have been fairly chill (since it‚Äôs the second last week of school and all assessments are done) which has help my sore head. ü§ß Can anyone else relate? #cmonschoolholidays

Prac Day 20:
All that marking I said I was going to do over the weekend? Yeahhhhhh that‚Äôs didn‚Äôt happen and got extremely sick instead üëçüèºü§ß My class had an exam today and didn‚Äôt understand the meaning of silence. Prac Day 19:

Prac Day 18:
My life consists of constantly looking at this all day and night ü§ì trying to do uni assignments whilst on prac is a little bit of a struggle, but I‚Äôm slowly getting through it! Thankfully I had three free periods today, so that helped! ‚ú®

Prac Day 17:
This may look like a paper crane to the naked eye. üïä But in reality, this was given to me by a student who hated me at the beginning of prac, refused to listen or talk to me without being sarcastic and rude, and never once answered questions when asked. I am definitely losing track of time! ‚è∞Little bit anxious for my students are they have exams/assessments from tomorrow onwards. üò∞ I have given them EVERYTHING to prepare them for the exam, but I just don‚Äôt know if they appreciate/ understand how much I am helping them!
